countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

1.17 - Ensure IAM instance roles are used for AWS resource access from instances

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply AWS KMS encryption to SNS topics
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your SNS topics, it is recommended to enable Server-Side Encryption (SSE) using AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys. This will ensure that the data in your SNS topics is encrypted at rest, providing an additional layer of security. Below are the steps that a cloud engineer can follow to implement this control:

  1. Create a Customer Master Key (CMK): Before enabling SSE, ensure that you have a Customer Master Key (CMK) in AWS KMS. You can create a CMK through the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.
  2. Configure SNS Topic for SSE: To enable SSE for an SNS topic, use the AWS Management Console or AWS CLI to update the topic's attributes. Specify the ARN of the AWS KMS key that you want to use for encryption.
  3. Use the AWS Management Console:
    • Navigate to the Amazon SNS Dashboard.
    • Select the topic you want to encrypt.
    • Go to the "Encryption" tab and click "Edit".
    • Select "Enable".
    • Choose the KMS key you want to use from the dropdown menu.
    • Click "Save changes".
  4. Use the AWS CLI:aws sns set-topic-attributes --topic-arn <topic-arn> --attribute-name KmsMasterKeyId --attribute-value <kms-key-arn>
  5. Access Control: Ensure that appropriate IAM policies are in place to allow SNS to use the specified AWS KMS key. The IAM policy should grant sns:Publish and sns:Subscribe permissions.
  6. Monitoring and Auditing: Regularly monitor CloudTrail logs to audit the use of your AWS KMS keys and SNS topics for any unauthorized access or anomalies.

For more detailed information, refer to the AWS SNS Security documentation: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-security.html

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Apply strict SNS topic access policies
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS SNS topics, it is crucial to implement IAM (Identity and Access Management) policies that restrict access, ensuring that only authorized users can publish or subscribe to these topics. Adhere to the following guidelines based on AWS's security documentation:

Step-by-Step Guidance:

  1. Define the IAM Policy: Start by creating a policy that specifies the authorized actions (Publish, Subscribe, GetTopicAttributes, etc.) and the specific SNS topics these actions are allowed on. Use AWS managed policies or create customized policies as per your requirement.
  2. Attach the IAM Policy: Attach the policy to the IAM users, groups, or roles that need access to the SNS topics. This step ensures that only entities with the appropriate permissions can perform actions on the topics.
  3. Least Privilege Principle: Ensure that the policies follow the principle of least privilege, providing only the necessary permissions required for specific tasks and nothing more.
  4. Use Resource-Based Policies: In addition to IAM policies, consider using resource-based policies for further granularity. These policies can limit access directly on the SNS topic level.
  5. Monitor and Review: Regularly review and monitor the policies and access controls to ensure compliance with security policies and make adjustments as needed.

For more detailed information on setting up IAM policies for AWS SNS, refer to the official AWS SNS Topic Permissions Documentation and AWS SNS Security Best Practices.

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Disable raw HTTP endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Avoid configuring subscriptions to deliver to a raw http endpoints. Always have subscriptions delivering to an endpoint domain name. For example, a subscription configured to deliver to an endpoint, http://1.2.3.4/my-path, should be changed to http://my.domain.name/my-path.

For detailed information and additional recommendations, please refer to the official Amazon SNS Security Best Practices.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS SNS resource-based policies
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS SNS (Simple Notification Service) topics, implement resource-based policies to define and control who can access or modify your SNS topics. These policies enable finer control over permissions at the resource level, ensuring that only authorized entities have required permissions. Follow the steps below to implement resource-based policies:

Steps to Implement Resource-Based Policies:

  1. Navigate to SNS in the AWS Management Console: Open the Amazon SNS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/sns/v3/home.
  2. Select the Topic: From the navigation pane, choose Topics and then select the topic you want to secure.
  3. Edit Topic Policy: On the topic details page, choose Edit under the Access policy section.
  4. Define the Resource-Based Policy: Write a policy document in JSON format specifying the permissions for different AWS principals. The policy can include permissions for SNS actions such as Publish, Subscribe, Receive, and DeleteTopic. Example:{    "Version": "2012-10-17",    "Statement": [        {            "Effect": "Allow",            "Principal": {                "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::123456789012:user/Alice"            },            "Action": "sns:Publish",            "Resource": "arn:aws:sns:us-east-1:123456789012:MyTopic"        },        {            "Effect": "Deny",            "Principal": "*",            "Action": [                "sns:Publish",                "sns:Subscribe"            ],            "Resource": "arn:aws:sns:us-east-1:123456789012:MyTopic",            "Condition": {                "StringNotEquals": {                    "aws:PrincipalOrgID": "o-abcdefgh"                }            }        }    ] }        
  5. Apply and Save the Policy: After defining the policy, choose Save Changes to apply the policy to your SNS topic.

Refer to the official AWS SNS security guidelines for additional information and best practices: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-using-resource-based-policies.html.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Enable SNS delivery status logging
countermeasure.desc:
To track message delivery status for both successful and failed deliveries and identify potential issues, it is essential to enable Amazon SNS delivery status logs. By enabling the logging of delivery status, you can monitor, analyze, and take corrective actions based on the delivery outcomes. Here's how cloud engineers can implement this control using AWS SNS:

  1. Enable Delivery Status Logging:
    • Navigate to the Amazon SNS console.
    • Select the topic for which you want to track delivery status.
    • Edit the topic's settings and enable the "Delivery Status Logging" option under the "Delivery status logging" section.
    • Specify an Amazon S3 bucket or CloudWatch Logs for storing delivery status information.
  2. Configure Permissions:
    • Ensure that the SNS service has appropriate permissions to write to the specified Amazon S3 bucket or CloudWatch Logs.
    • Adjust the IAM policies attached to the SNS role or identity to allow write access to the chosen logging resource.
  3. Monitor and Analyze Logs:
    • Regularly review the delivery status logs to identify trends, successful deliveries, and any delivery failures.
    • Use CloudWatch Alarms to set thresholds and get notified of specific patterns in the logs, such as a high rate of delivery failures.
    • Analyze logs to diagnose and address issues, such as misconfigurations or downstream service availability.

For detailed security best practices and additional information, refer to the official AWS SNS security documentation: AWS SNS Security Guidelines.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized topic access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control settings on SNS topics can result in unauthorized parties gaining access to publish or subscribe to the topics, which may lead to potential data leakage or misuse.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized parties, including malicious actors or inadvertent insiders, exploiting weak or misconfigured access control policies to gain unauthorized publish/subscribe privileges.
Impacts
Data leakage, miscommunication, information misuse, possible regulatory non-compliance, and overall degradation of the system's integrity and security posture.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a poorly secured SNS topic and subscribes to or publishes misleading information, causing confusion and potential harm to the organization. Another scenario could involve an insider accidentally misconfiguring permissions, leading to unintended data exposure.

threat.name: Insufficient encryption of messages
threat.desc:
General threat description
Messages transmitted via SNS topics are vulnerable to interception or unauthorized access if encryption measures are not properly implemented.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized parties, including malicious insiders or external attackers, may exploit weak or absent encryption to intercept messages. Common attack vectors include network sniffing or exploiting misconfigured access permissions.
Impacts
Sensitive information within the intercepted messages could be exposed, leading to potential data breaches, monetary losses, legal consequences, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a network sniffing tool to capture unencrypted messages transmitted to an SNS topic, revealing confidential information such as customer data or internal communications. Alternatively, an attacker gains unauthorized access through misconfigured SNS topic permissions and retrieves unencrypted messages directly.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper logging and monitoring, malicious activities or unauthorized access to SNS topics may go unnoticed.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include external attackers, malicious insiders, or any unauthorized users who have gained access to the AWS environment through means such as compromised accounts or credential theft.
Impacts
The impacts can range from unauthorized data access, dissemination of sensitive information, disruption of notification services, to potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to SNS topics and subscribes a malicious endpoint, thereby exfiltrating sensitive data. Alternatively, a compromised account could send unauthorized messages, causing operational disruption or disseminating false information to subscribers.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through raw HTTP endpoints
threat.desc:
General threat description
Utilizing HTTP endpoints for message delivery can expose the messages to interception or unauthorized access. This can lead to sensitive information being compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors intercepting HTTP traffic or gaining unauthorized access to HTTP endpoints.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive information, data breaches, and potential regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts an HTTP message containing sensitive data during transit. An unauthorized user gains access to an HTTP endpoint and retrieves confidential messages.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-345
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-345: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-502
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data The product deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure all sensitive data is encrypted both at rest and in transit to protect against unauthorized access.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Identify sensitive data that requires encryption based on classification and regulatory requirements.
  2. Use strong encryption algorithms and manage keys securely using a dedicated key management system.
  3. Configure encryption for all data storage solutions, including databases, file systems, and backups.
  4. Ensure that data transmission channels use protocols such as TLS/SSL for secure communication.
  5. Regularly review and update encryption policies to align with evolving security standards.

Implementing these steps will significantly reduce the risk of sensitive data exposure.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enhance file logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Implement comprehensive logging and monitoring to detect and respond to unauthorized file access and modifications.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Enable detailed logging for all file access and modification activities.
  2. Use centralized logging solutions to collect and analyze log data.
  3. Set up alerts for suspicious activities or patterns indicative of security incidents.
  4. Regularly review and audit log files to ensure they provide complete and accurate records.
  5. Implement real-time monitoring tools to detect and respond to threats promptly.

Implementing these steps will enhance your ability to detect and respond to unauthorized file activities.

Use file integrity monitoring (FIM) tools to detect unauthorized changes to files.

Implement cryptographic hashes to verify the integrity of critical files.

Regularly back up files and store backups securely.

Implement access controls to limit who can modify files.

Enable versioning to track changes and revert to previous versions if tampering is detected.

countermeasure.name: Implement metadata integrity checks
countermeasure.desc:
Use integrity checking mechanisms to monitor and protect file metadata from unauthorized modifications.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Employ file integrity monitoring (FIM) tools to track changes in file metadata.
  2. Regularly audit file permissions, ownership, and other metadata attributes to ensure they are correctly configured.
  3. Use cryptographic methods to ensure the integrity of critical metadata.
  4. Set up alerts for unauthorized changes to file metadata and take immediate action to address them.
  5. Educate administrators on the importance of metadata integrity and how to maintain it.

Implementing these steps will help maintain the integrity of file metadata and prevent unauthorized modifications.

countermeasure.name: Implement robust access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implement strict access control mechanisms using principles of least privilege and need-to-know.

Regularly audit and update ACLs to ensure they are correctly configured.

Use encryption to protect sensitive files both at rest and in transit.

Implement monitoring and logging to detect unauthorized access attempts.

Educate employees about the importance of file security and proper handling procedures.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Secure file upload handling
countermeasure.desc:
Validate and sanitize all uploaded files to ensure they do not contain malicious code.

Implement file type restrictions to allow only safe file formats.

Use antivirus software to scan uploaded files for malware.

Store uploaded files in isolated directories and execute them in a sandbox environment.

Educate users about the risks of uploading and sharing files from untrusted sources.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Ransomware encrypting files
threat.desc:
General threat description: Ransomware encrypts files and demands a ransom for their decryption, causing data loss and operational disruptions.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Cybercriminals distribute ransomware through phishing emails, malicious websites, or exploiting software vulnerabilities.

Impacts: Loss of access to critical data, financial loss, operational downtime, and potential data breach.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An employee opens a malicious email attachment, triggering ransomware that encrypts the companys file server.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in remote desktop services to deploy ransomware.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Malware infection via file uploads
threat.desc:
General threat description: Malware infection via file uploads occurs when an attacker uploads malicious files that are executed or processed by the system, leading to compromise.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers upload infected files through web applications or email attachments.

Impacts: System compromise, data loss, and propagation of malware.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uploads a file containing a script that exploits a vulnerability in the file processing service.
  • A user inadvertently uploads a document infected with a macro virus.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized file access
threat.desc:
General threat description: Unauthorized file access occurs when an attacker gains access to files without proper authorization, potentially leading to data breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, malware, or exploited vulnerabilities in software can lead to unauthorized access.

Impacts: Exposure of sensitive information, financial loss, legal consequences, and damage to reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the file system to bypass ACLs and access confidential documents.
  • A disgruntled employee uses elevated permissions to access and exfiltrate proprietary information.

threat.name: Sensitive data exposure due to inadequate encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description: Sensitive data exposure occurs when files containing confidential information are not properly encrypted, making them vulnerable to unauthorized access.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, or malware can exploit weak or absent encryption mechanisms.

Impacts: Data breaches, financial loss, legal consequences, and damage to reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker intercepts data being transmitted over an unencrypted channel.
  • A malicious insider accesses and exfiltrates unencrypted sensitive files from the storage.

threat.name: Insufficient file logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description: Insufficient file logging and monitoring can lead to delayed detection of unauthorized access, tampering, or other malicious activities.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, or malware can exploit the lack of comprehensive logging and monitoring.

Impacts: Delayed response to security incidents, data breaches, and operational disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker accesses sensitive files without being detected due to lack of logging.
  • Unauthorized modifications to critical files go unnoticed, leading to data integrity issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: File corruption or tampering
threat.desc:
General threat description: File corruption or tampering occurs when an attacker modifies files, potentially leading to data integrity issues and unauthorized alterations.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malware, or malicious insiders can alter file contents or metadata.

Impacts: Data integrity compromise, operational disruptions, and loss of trust in the data.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker injects malicious code into executable files to introduce malware.
  • A malicious insider alters financial records to commit fraud.

threat.name: Unauthorized modification of file metadata
threat.desc:
General threat description: Unauthorized modification of file metadata occurs when an attacker alters metadata information such as file permissions, ownership, or timestamps, leading to potential misuse or abuse of the file system.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, or malware can exploit vulnerabilities in file system management.

Impacts: Data integrity issues, unauthorized access, and operational disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker changes the file permissions to gain unauthorized access to sensitive files.
  • A malicious insider alters timestamps to cover up unauthorized activities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

countermeasure.name: Choose the optimal authentication method for AWS AppSync
countermeasure.desc:
When securing AWS AppSync endpoints, it is essential to use appropriate authentication mechanisms to ensure that only authorized entities can access the resources. Heres a guide on how to implement these authentication methods effectively:

API Keys

API keys are a simple way of authenticating API requests. They can be used for applications where you need a straightforward method of providing access, without the need for complex mechanisms. To implement API keys:

  • Navigate to your AWS AppSync console.
  • Select your API and go to the "Settings" tab.
  • Under "API Keys", create a new key and configure the expiration period appropriately to ensure periodic rotation.

Note that API keys provide no encryption or _scope restriction_ and should be used with care, particularly in public-facing or less secure environments.

AWS IAM

AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) is a robust way to authenticate API requests for users within your AWS account. To enable IAM authorization:

  • Open your AppSync API settings and choose "Add Authorization Mode".
  • Select "AWS IAM".
  • Ensure that your IAM roles and policies are configured correctly to grant access to the AWS AppSync endpoints based on the principle of least privilege.

This method is beneficial for server-side applications where you manage AWS credentials securely.

Amazon Cognito

Amazon Cognito provides user sign-up, sign-in, and access control for web and mobile apps. To integrate Cognito with AppSync:

  • Create a new Amazon Cognito User Pool and identity pool via the Cognito console.
  • Within your AppSync API settings, add a new authorization mode and select "Amazon Cognito User Pool".
  • Configure the User Pool details as needed.

Using Cognito simplifies the process of handling different user identities and their associated permissions.

OpenID Connect

OpenID Connect (OIDC) provides an authentication layer on top of OAuth 2.0 to verify users based on an authorization server. To implement OIDC:

  • Register your app with an OpenID Connect provider like Google, Auth0, etc., and obtain the necessary client credentials.
  • In the AWS AppSync console, choose "Add Authorization Mode" and select "OpenID Connect".
  • Fill in the required OpenID Connect configuration details.

This method allows the use of external identity providers for user authentication, simplifying federated access to the API.

For detailed guidance on these mechanisms and more security best practices, refer to the official AWS AppSync Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use TLS for HTTP resolvers
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of data in transit between AWS AppSync and HTTP resolvers, it is essential to enforce the use of Transport Layer Security (TLS) for all communications. TLS provides encryption, ensuring that data transmitted between the client and the server remains confidential and tamper-proof.

Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Configure HTTPS Endpoints: Ensure that all HTTP resolvers are configured to use HTTPS endpoints, which inherently support TLS. This configuration should be made in the AppSync GraphQL schema where the HTTP resolver is defined. For example: 
    {
  "version": "2018-05-29",
  "method": "POST",
  "resourcePath": "/graphql",
  "params": {
    "body": "{\"query\":\"query { ... }\"}",
    "headers": {
      "Content-Type": "application/json"
    }
  }
}
  2. Verify Server Certificates: Ensure that the server certificates for the HTTPS endpoints are valid and trusted. This step is crucial to avoid man-in-the-middle attacks. Consider using AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) to manage and deploy TLS certificates easily.
  3. Audit and Monitoring: Regularly audit your AppSync API calls to ensure compliance with the TLS requirement. Set up AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch logs to monitor for non-TLS compliant requests and take corrective actions as needed.

Refer to the official AWS AppSync Best Practices for more detailed information.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data transmitted over unsecured channels can be intercepted, allowing attackers to capture sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can employ man-in-the-middle attacks, eavesdropping, or packet sniffing tools to intercept data transmitted over insecure channels such as HTTP instead of HTTPS.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi access point, intercepting traffic between a user's device and AWS AppSync, capturing sensitive data like authentication tokens or user information. Alternatively, an attacker uses packet sniffing tools on a compromised network to intercept unencrypted API calls between AppSync and other AWS services.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Weak authentication settings.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious attackers exploiting weak authentication mechanisms to gain access. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access, data theft, data manipulation, and potential data loss. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits insufficient password policies to guess or brute-force a users credentials, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data within AppSync. Alternatively, poor implementation of multi-factor authentication allows an attacker to bypass controls and manipulate data.

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events

countermeasure.name: Enforce code-signed Lambda deployments with AWS Signer
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that only vetted code reaches production by pairing AWS Signer with a Lambda Code Signing Configuration (CSC): every deployment package must be signed with your approved signing profile before Lambda accepts it.

  1. Create a signing profile
    1. aws signer put-signing-profile \
       --profile-name prod-lambda-code \
       --platform-id AWSLambda-SHA384-ECDSA
  2. Store the profile ARN in your CI/CD secrets.
  3. Integrate signing into the pipeline
    • Package the ZIP or container image, then call aws signer start-signing-job (ZIP) or ECR image signing (container).
    • Fail the build if the signing job status isnt Succeeded.
  4. Define a Code Signing Configuration
    1. aws lambda create-code-signing-config \
       --allowed-publishers SigningProfileVersionArns=arn:aws:signer::profile/prod-lambda-code/* \
       --code-signing-policies UntrustedArtifactOnDeployment=Enforce
  5. Enforce blocks any unsigned or differently-signed artifact.
  6. Attach the CSC to functions
    1. aws lambda update-function-code-signing-config \
       --function-name orders-handler \
       --code-signing-config-arn arn:aws:lambda::code-signing-config:csc-abc123
  7. Include this step in all CloudFormation/Terraform modules so drift is impossible.
  8. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable the AWS Config rule lambda-function-code-signing-config-enabled to detect functions without a CSC.
    • Use EventBridge to alert when a deployment fails due to CodeSigningError, signalling a bypass attempt or pipeline mis-sign.
  9. Key hygiene
    • Rotate the Signer KMS key annually; update the signing profile to the new key version.
    • Restrict signer:StartSigningJob permission to the build role; deny it in production accounts via SCPs.

By requiring AWS-signed packages and enforcing CSCs, you shut the door on tampered artifacts, typo-squatted libraries, and shadow deployments.

References

  • Code signing for AWS Lambda
  • AWS Signer Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Enforce tagging standards on Lambda functions
countermeasure.desc:
Every Lambda function must carry a complete, standardized tag set for example Environment, Owner, CostCenter, and Compliance so that security, cost-allocation, and automation workflows can rely on consistent metadata.

How to implement

  1. Define the mandatory keys in a central document (e.g., tagging-standard.md) and publish it to your IaC repository.
  2. Validate in the pipeline
    • Add a build step (cfn-lint/Checkov/GitHub Action, etc.) that fails if the template or aws lambda create-function command omits any required tag.
  3. Enforce at runtime with AWS Config
    • Enable the managed rule required-tags or deploy a custom rule that checks the AWS::Lambda::Function resource type and your mandatory tag list.
    • Configure the rule for continuous evaluation and send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket.
  4. Auto-remediate or quarantine
    • Attach an EventBridge rule to run an SSM Automation or Lambda fixer script that adds missing tagsor, in strict environments, disables the function until tags are corrected.
  5. Review quarterly
    • Spot-check tag accuracy (e.g., does the Owner tag still map to an active identity?) and update the standard when new reporting requirements appear.

Automated tagging enforcement guarantees that every Lambda function can be located, costed, and governed, while eliminating drift caused by manual provisioning.

References

  • Tagging Lambda functions
  • AWS Config rule required-tags

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with perfect-forward-secrecy for all Lambda traffic
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every network path that carries AWS Lambda control-plane or data-plane trafficCLI / SDK calls to the Lambda API, Function URLs, ALB/API Gateway invokes, VPC egress, and third-party integrationsnegotiates TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 using PFS cipher suites (ECDHE or DHE). Disable legacy SSL/TLS versions and static-key ciphers to eliminate downgrade and session-key compromise risks.

Implementation guidance

  1. Runtime & library hardening
    • Use current AWS SDKs, AWS CLI v2, and OS packages (OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181, .NET 4.6) that default to TLS 1.2+.
    • In container images or AMIs set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 and remove *_RSA_* suites from the cipher list.
  2. Outbound Lambda networking
    • When the function runs in a VPC, allow only TCP 443 to interface endpoints (S3, STS, Secrets Manager, etc.). Block port 80 in security groups and route tables.
    • For external calls, pin the destination to https:// URIs and verify certificates (e.g., with Python requests.verify=True).
  3. Inbound invoke paths
    • Function URLs: set AuthType=AWS_IAM or another auth method; TLS is auto-enforced by AWS but add a WAF rule that blocks any request with the X-Forwarded-Proto != https.
    • API Gateway / ALB: enable TLS 1.2 minimum on the custom domain or listener policy; prefer ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06.
    • For IoT or custom MQTT, use certificates that advertise only TLS 1.2/1.3 and EC cipher suites.
  4. Central guardrails
    • Attach an SCP that denies lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl or execute-api:Invoke when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy AWS Config rules or cfn-nag checks that fail if an ALB listener policy includes TLS 1.0/1.1 or if a VPC security group permits port 80 egress.
  5. Continuous verification
    • Add a CI test that attempts openssl s_client -connect lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 and expect failure; succeed with -tls1_2.
    • Scan AMIs and containers monthly with Inspector or OpenSCAP for outdated OpenSSL/LibreSSL versions.
  6. Incident response & patching
    • Subscribe to AWS Security Bulletins; redeploy all Lambda runtime layers when critical TLS CVEs are announced.
    • Rotate any function URL or API Gateway custom certificates that use deprecated algorithms (RSA-1024, SHA-1).

Following this control guarantees strong, modern encryption end-to-end, satisfying compliance frameworks and protecting Lambda workloads against passive interception and forward-decryption attacks.

References

  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum for all AWS service endpoints
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda security

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Grant least-privilege IAM permissions to Lambda execution roles
countermeasure.desc:
Create a dedicated IAM role for every Lambda function and attach only the permissions the code truly needsnothing more, nothing wildcard.

  1. Inventory required actions
    • List each AWS API the function calls (e.g., dynamodb:PutItem, s3:GetObject, secretsmanager:GetSecretValue).
    • Add logs:CreateLogGroup, logs:CreateLogStream, and logs:PutLogEvents for basic logging if they arent provided by a shared policy.
  2. Author a scoped policy
    • Restrict Resource to exact ARNs (specific table, bucket prefix, secret) instead of *.
    • Where possible, add condition keysfor example dynamodb:LeadingKeys, s3:prefix, aws:SourceVpc, or tagbased conditions.
  3. Attach the policy to a unique execution role
    • Console: Configuration Permissions choose or create role.
    • IaC example (CloudFormation):
      • LambdaRole:
         Type: AWS::IAM::Role
         Properties:
           AssumeRolePolicyDocument:
             Statement:
               - Effect: Allow
                 Principal: Service: lambda.amazonaws.com
                 Action: sts:AssumeRole
           Policies:
             - PolicyName: OrdersFunctionPolicy
               PolicyDocument: {...}   # actions/resources from step 2
  4. Remove default privileges
    • Delete unused AWS-managed policies like AWSLambdaFullAccess.
    • Never attach AdministratorAccess or * actionsfail the pipeline if these appear.
  5. Continuous validation
    • Enable IAM Access Analyzer unused permissions and prune actions that havent been called for 90 days.
    • Deploy AWS Config rule iam-managed-policy-check or a cfn-nag/Checkov rule in CI to block wildcard actions or resources.
  6. Review regularly
    • Re-run Access Analyzer after each feature release.
    • Rotate any secrets or keys the function accesses, updating the role policy as needed.

Applying strict, role-specific policies limits blast radius, supports the principle of least privilege, and satisfies compliance auditors looking for excessive permissions.

References

  • Security best practices for AWS Lambda
  • IAM Access Analyzer

countermeasure.name: Isolate Lambda network traffic with locked-down VPC subnets and security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Run every Lambda function inside a dedicated set of private subnets and attach it to a least-privilege security group so the function can reach only the services it truly needsnothing else.

How to implement

  1. Create lambda-only private subnets
    • Place them in the application VPC but do not route them to an Internet Gateway.
    • If outbound internet access is required, send traffic through a shared NAT Gateway or a VPC endpoint (for S3, DynamoDB, etc.).
  2. Define a restrictive security group
    • Egress rules: allow only the ports and CIDRs (or other SGs) that correspond to your dependenciesfor example, TCP 5432 to an RDS SG, HTTPS (443) to a Secrets Manager VPC endpoint SG. Remove the default all traffic egress rule.
    • Ingress rules: normally none are required; Lambda creates connections out of the subnet. If the function must be called by an internal ALB, allow only that ALBs SG on the listener port.
  3. Attach the VPC config to the function
    1. aws lambda update-function-configuration \
       --function-name payment-handler \
       --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0aa123,subnet-0bb456 \
                   SecurityGroupIds=sg-0lambda
  4. Guardrails and drift detection
    • Add an AWS Config rule (or cfn-nag/Checkov policy) that fails if a Lambda SG allows 0.0.0.0/0 or if the subnet route table points to an Internet Gateway.
    • Monitor VPC Flow Logs for unexpected destinations; tighten SG rules when new patterns appear.
  5. Document and review
    • Keep subnet IDs and SG IDs in your IaC modules so every environment uses the same isolation model.
    • Re-evaluate access rules quarterly or whenever the functions dependencies change.

Locking Lambda functions into isolated subnets and SGs minimizes lateral movement, reduces the attack surface, and satisfies segmentation requirements without sacrificing performance.

References

  • Configuring a Lambda function to access VPC resources
  • AWS Lambda security best practices network isolation

countermeasure.name: Keep Lambda functions on supported runtimes
countermeasure.desc:
AWS periodically deprecates Lambda runtimes (Node .js, Python, Java, .NET, Ruby, Go). A function that keeps running on an out-of-support runtime no longer receives security patches, and AWS may block deployments after the end-of-life date.

Implementation guidance

  1. Baseline now list every function and its runtime:
    1. aws lambda list-functions --query 'Functions[*].[FunctionName,Runtime]' --output table

Flag anything marked deprecated in the [runtime support policy].

  1. Automate continuous checks
    • Enable the managed AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime (or a custom rule) so any function on an outdated runtime is immediately marked NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Forward Config notifications to an SNS topic tied to your ticketing system or ChatOps channel.
  2. Update promptly
    • Track AWS deprecation announcements; add the EOL date to your backlog.
    • Use feature branches to bump the runtime version in your IaC (SAM/CloudFormation/Terraform) and CI pipeline, run tests, then deploy.
    • For container images, rebuild from an up-to-date base image and push a new tag.
  3. Prevent drift
    • Add a pipeline gate that rejects any create-function or update-function-configuration call if the --runtime flag is not in your approved list.
    • For containers, scan the image in CodeBuild/CodePipeline with AWS Inspector or Trivy before deployment.
  4. Review quarterly
    Re-run the baseline script or a Config compliance report; remove any temporary suppression and schedule upgrades for newly announced EOL runtimes.

Keeping all functions on supported runtimes guarantees ongoing security patches, performance optimisations, and access to the latest Lambda features.

References

  • AWS Lambda runtimes supported versions and deprecation policy
  • AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime

countermeasure.name: Log all Lambda API activity with CloudTrail and secure S3 storage
countermeasure.desc:
Create an organization-wide, multi-Region CloudTrail trail that records every AWS Lambda management eventfunction creation, configuration updates, permission changes, InvokeFunction calls, and Function URL operationsand delivers the logs to a hardened S3 bucket for long-term retention and forensic search.

Implementation steps

  1. Enable a multi-Region trail
    • Console: CloudTrail Trails Create trail select Apply trail to all Regions and log Management events Read + Write (Lambda is covered automatically).
    • CLI / IaC example:
      • aws cloudtrail create-trail \
         --name org-lambda-trail \
         --s3-bucket-name org-trail-logs \
         --is-multi-region-trail
        aws cloudtrail start-logging --name org-lambda-trail
  2. Protect the S3 log bucket
    • Block public access and require TLS in the bucket policy:
      • "Condition": { "Bool": { "aws:SecureTransport": "false" } }
    • Enable SSE-KMS encryption with a customer-managed key; limit key-policy access to the CloudTrail service principal and your security team.
    • Turn on log file validation and bucket versioning to detect tampering.
  3. Retention & analytics
    • Apply lifecycle rules: e.g., keep logs in the S3 Standard tier for 90 days, then transition to Glacier Instant Retrieval or Deep Archive, deleting after seven years.
    • Optionally send the trail to CloudWatch Logs or Lake Formation for near-real-time detection and SQL-based hunting.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Deploy AWS Config rules such as cloudtrail-enabled and s3-bucket-server-side-encryption-enabled so any drift triggers alerts.
    • Create EventBridge rules that notify your on-call channel when someone issues StopLogging, DeleteTrail, or changes the bucket policy.
  5. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, confirm that new AWS Regions and new Lambda features are still captured, and rotate or disable unused KMS keys and IAM principals.
    • Validate integrity with aws cloudtrail validate-logs during tabletop or incident-response exercises.

Implementing centralized, secure CloudTrail logging for Lambda provides an immutable audit trail that supports compliance, incident response, and continuous improvement of your serverless security posture.

References

  • Logging AWS Lambda API calls with AWS CloudTrail
  • Best practices for CloudTrail log file integrity and S3 security

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

countermeasure.name: Monitor package hash and bootstrap integrity
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing robust security countermeasures for AWS Lambda custom runtimes involves the following steps:

  1. Record Approved CodeSha256:
    • For every deployment of AWS Lambda, compute the CodeSha256 hash of the deployed function package using the AWS CLI or SDK.
    • Maintain an allowlist of approved CodeSha256 hashes in a secure system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or a Configuration Management Database (CMDB) with audit logs enabled for modifications.
  2. Monitor Drift through EventBridge:
    • Create an EventBridge rule to capture UpdateFunctionCode events from CloudTrail. Configure CloudTrail to log all function updates to ensure full visibility of unplanned changes.
    • When an UpdateFunctionCode event is triggered, invoke a Lambda function or automation workflow that runs get-function against the affected Lambda function.
    • Compare the reported CodeSha256 from get-function output against the stored allowlist of approved hashes.
    • If a discrepancy is identified, create a high-severity finding and alert relevant teams immediately using an integrated mechanism such as AWS Security Hub or Amazon SNS.
  3. Verify Integrity During CI/CD:
    • In your CI/CD pipeline, compute and store a checksum for the bootstrap file (or its layer path) during the packaging step of Lambda custom runtimes.
    • For container-based runtimes, capture the digests of the container image and validate the ENTRYPOINT and CMD against the approved baselines stored during CI.
    • Post-deploy, verify the deployed checksums match the precomputed checksums from the CI/CD pipeline.
  4. Persist Integrity Metadata:
    • Store integrity metadata such as approved hashes, container digests, and runtime file checksums in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store, with secure access controls to limit modifications to authorized personnel or automation scripts.
    • Enable versioning and tagging for stored metadata to support audit trails and provide recovery options in case of accidental modifications.
  5. Detect Unauthorized Bootstrap Changes:
    • Ensure that bootstrap file integrity validation is part of runtime monitoring. Regularly automate hash comparisons and include mechanisms for detecting tampering during runtime or in transit.
    • Integrate findings from the above monitoring mechanisms into AWS Security Hub or a centralized incident management tool for triage and resolution.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda CodeSha256
  • Using CloudTrail with Amazon EventBridge
  • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store
  • AWS Security Hub
