countermeasure.name: Require AWS_IAM authentication on Lambda function URLs
countermeasure.desc:
When you expose an AWS Lambda function through a Function URL, set the AuthType to AWS_IAM so that every invoke request must be SigV4-signed by an IAM principal with an explicit allow on lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl. This prevents unauthenticated internet traffic from reaching the function and lets you apply fine-grained least-privilege policies, MFA enforcement, and session-duration limits.

Implementation steps

  1. Create or update the Function URL
    1. aws lambda create-function-url-config \
         --function-name orders-handler \
         --auth-type AWS_IAM \
         --cors AllowedOrigins=https://app.example.com
      #or
      aws lambda update-function-url-config \
         --function-name orders-handler \
         --auth-type AWS_IAM
  2. Authorize callers
    • Add an IAM policy that allows lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl on the function ARN with /url suffix:
      arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:123456789012:function:orders-handler:url
    • Scope the policy to trusted roles or users; require MFA or session tags if needed.
  3. Invoke securely
    • Clients must include an Authorization header with a SigV4 signature (aws4_request).
    • For browsers, front the URL with API Gateway or CloudFront signed cookies if you cant sign requests client-side.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Deploy an AWS Config rule or SCP that prevents AuthType: NONE in production accounts.
    • Stream Lambda access logs to CloudWatch; alert on 403 errors to detect unauthorized attempts.

Using AWS_IAM authentication ensures only vetted principals can reach the function, leveraging the full power of IAM policies and audit trails.

References

  • Using IAM authorization for Lambda function URLs
  • lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl permissions and examples

countermeasure.name: Require MFA for root and IAM users
countermeasure.desc:
Protect the AWS account against credential theft by enforcing multi-factor authentication (MFA) on the root user and every IAM user:

  1. Enable MFA devices
    • Root user: sign in as root and register a hardware key, FIDO2 passkey, or virtual TOTP device at Account Security credentials Multi-factor authentication.
    • IAM users: in the IAM console or CLI (aws iam enable-mfa-device), attach a virtual or hardware MFA device to each user. Automate user creation so MFA is required before console access is granted.
  2. Block sessions without MFA
    • Attach an IAM policy that denies all actions when aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent is false.
    • Apply an SCP at the OU or root level that prevents non-MFA console logins in production accounts.
  3. Monitor and enforce
    • Turn on AWS Config managed rules root-account-mfa-enabled and iam-user-mfa-enabled; alert when they report NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Stream CloudTrail to Security Hub and create findings if DeactivateMFADevice, DeleteVirtualMFADevice, or root logins without MFA occur.
  4. Operational hygiene
    • Register two MFA devices for the root user (primary and backup).
    • Review the IAM credential report monthly; disable or delete any user lacking MFA or with unused access keys.

Implementing mandatory MFA shuts down most credential-stuffing, phishing, and console-token replay attacks, forming the first and strongest line of defense for all Lambda-related and broader AWS operations.

References

  • Enable MFA for the root user
  • Using MFA with IAM users

countermeasure.name: Restrict lambda resource-based policies to explicit principals
countermeasure.desc:
Whenever you add a resource-based policy to a Lambda function (e.g., when granting another AWS account, an AWS service, or an API Gateway permission to invoke it), list only the exact IAM principal ARNs or service principals that require access.
Do not use wildcard principals ("*"), anonymous principals, or broad AWS service wildcards ("lambda.amazonaws.com" without conditions). Wildcards expose the function to unintended callers and defeat least-privilege design.

implementation checklist

  1. author precise statements
    1. {
       "Effect": "Allow",
       "Principal": { "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::444455556666:role/PaymentService" },
       "Action": "lambda:InvokeFunction",
       "Resource": "arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:111122223333:function:ProcessPayment"
      }
  2. Specify the consuming account ID and role name; for cross-account access, pair with aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount condition keys.
  3. block wildcards in CI/CD
    • Add cfn-nag / Checkov / cfn-guard rules that fail a build if Principal equals "*" or if no Condition keys are present for an AWS service principal.
  4. continuous compliance
    • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-public-access-prohibited (or a custom rule) to detect policies with public or wildcard principals and mark them NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Subscribe Security Hub to forward findings to your on-call channel so unintended permissions are fixed immediately.
  5. review quarterly
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer to enumerate current function resource policies and highlight new external principals.
    • Remove any stale or unused permissions.

Adhering to explicit-principal policies limits who can invoke or manage your Lambda functions, sharply reducing the risk of unauthorized access or privilege escalation.

References

  • Controlling access with resource-based policies for Lambda
  • AWS Config managed rule

countermeasure.name: Restrict UpdateFunctionCode and enforce immutable release flow
countermeasure.desc:
1. Restrict IAM permissions for Lambda updates:
    • Create or update IAM policies to restrict the lambda:UpdateFunctionCode and lambda:PublishVersion actions to a dedicated CI/CD principal.
    • Implement permission boundaries or Service Control Policies (SCPs) to enforce restrictions across accounts. Examples include denying human users access to these actions entirely in production environments.
    • Test the IAM policies with tools such as AWS IAM Access Analyzer to ensure that only the CI principal has access to these sensitive actions.
  2. Enforce code signing during deployment:
    • Enable and configure Lambda Code Signing by creating a code signing configuration (CSC) that includes trusted signing profiles.
    • Update deployment workflows to use the CSC. Add IAM conditions such as lambda:CodeSigningConfigArn to ensure that only signed artifacts can be deployed.
    • Use versions and aliases to promote changes instead of enabling direct edits:
      • Publish a new function version after deployment.
      • Update aliases to point explicitly to the new version.
  3. Disallow edits to the $LATEST version in production:
    • Disable direct updates to the $LATEST function version for production accounts using IAM policies.
    • Implement governance practices that require testing and approval in staging environments before updating versions or aliases in production.
  4. Establish integrity monitoring and alerts:
    • Enable AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config to track events related to Lambda code updates, especially UpdateFunctionCode and PublishVersion.
    • Create Amazon CloudWatch alarms or EventBridge rules for detecting unauthorized edits or direct code updates, both via the AWS Management Console and SDK.
    • Set up automated workflows to quarantine compromised functions:
      • Disable traffic to affected aliases if integrity verification fails.
      • Notify security teams for manual review and approval.
  5. Implement immutable and auditable CI/CD pipelines:
    • Design CI/CD workflows that ensure all artifacts deployed are code-signed and verified.
    • Adopt tools such as AWS CodePipeline or external pipelines like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, etc., to enforce versioning and signing practices.
    • Use version control systems and tags to establish traceable records for every production release.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Code Signing
  • IAM Permission Boundaries
  • Service Control Policies (SCPs)
  • AWS CodePipeline
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS CloudTrail

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity

countermeasure.name: Use PrivateLink interface endpoints for Lambda and supporting services
countermeasure.desc:
Create interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for AWS Lambda and every service the function relies onLambda control plane (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda), Function URLs (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda-url), and supporting endpoints such as S3, ECR API/ECR DKR, CloudWatch Logs, KMS, DynamoDB, SQS, or Kinesisso that all deployment, invoke, and dependency traffic stays on the AWS backbone instead of the public internet.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet selection choose at least two private subnets in different Availability Zones to give Lambda enough ENIs for scaling and AZ-level resilience.
  2. Provision endpoints create each endpoint with the AWS CLI or IaC:
    1. aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \
         --vpc-id vpc-1234abcd \
         --service-name com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.lambda \
         --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \
         --subnet-ids subnet-a subnet-b \
         --security-group-ids sg-lambda-endpoints
  3. keep Private DNS enabled so the standard service hostname automatically resolves to the VPC-local IPs.
  4. Harden network access attach a security group that allows only TCP 443 from Lambda subnets or CI/CD hosts; block port 80 entirely.
  5. Apply endpoint policies restrict calls to the exact actions your workload needs (e.g., lambda:InvokeFunction, lambda:GetLayerVersion) and, if required, add aws:SourceVpce or aws:SourceVpc conditions for defense-in-depth.
  6. Lock function resource policies when using Function URLs or cross-account invokes, include StringEquals {"aws:SourceVpce":"vpce-"} so internet-sourced requests are rejected even if a public path exists.
  7. Validate from a private instance run dig lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com and confirm it returns a 10.x address; disable the NAT Gateway temporarily and verify that deployments and invokes still succeed.
  8. Monitor and audit enable VPC Flow Logs for the endpoint ENIs, set CloudWatch alarms on rejected flows, and add an AWS Config rule that flags production VPCs missing the Lambda endpoint.

PrivateLink keeps Lambda control-plane and data traffic inside AWS, reduces latency, simplifies firewall rules, and satisfies compliance mandates that prohibit internet egress for sensitive workloads.

References

  • Interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for Lambda
  • AWS PrivateLink basics and best practices

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Use temporary credentials via AWS STS
countermeasure.desc:
Give every Lambda function, service, CI/CD pipeline, and human operator an IAM role to assume rather than a static IAM user with access-key pairs. When a principal assumes the role, AWS Security Token Service (STS) hands back short-lived credentials (default 1 h) that AWS rotates automatically. This removes permanent secrets from code, cuts the blast radius of a leaked key, and lets you attach granular, least-privilege policies to each role.

Implementation steps

  1. Create purpose-built roles one per Lambda function (execution role) and one per developer or automation persona. Scope policies to the minimum actions and resources needed.
  2. Configure assumption paths
    • AWS services: add the service principal (e.g., lambda.amazonaws.com, codebuild.amazonaws.com) to the roles trust policy so it can call sts:AssumeRole.
    • Humans/federation: use IAM Identity Center, SAML, or OIDC to let users assume their role after MFA.
  3. Remove static keys disable or delete legacy IAM users and hard-coded keys; store only the role ARN in configuration.
  4. Set sensible session limits keep MaxSessionDuration low (15 min1 h for interactive work; 12 h for workloads).
  5. Monitor & audit enable CloudTrail and IAM Access Analyzer to track who assumes which role; alert on unexpected roles or unusually long sessions.

Adopting STS-based roles wipes out long-lived credentials, enforces just-in-time access, and aligns with AWS recommended security posture.

References

  • Temporary credentials with AWS STS
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda IAM roles

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: SingleAZ failure for VPC functions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions are placed in a VPC that spans only a single Availability Zone, an AZ outage (due to hardware failure, networking issues, or scheduled maintenance) renders those functions unable to access their ENIs, subnets, or dependent servicescausing complete service disruption.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • AWS Infrastructure Failures: Power, network, or hardware faults isolated to one AZ.
  • Misconfiguration: VPC subnet or NAT gateway deployment limited to a single AZ.
  • Capacity Events: AZspecific resource exhaustion (e.g., ENI limits reached) preventing new function attachments.

Impacts

  • Service Outage: Affected Lambdas cannot execute, disrupting APIs, event processing, or backend jobs.
  • Data Delays: Queues and streams back up, leading to timesensitive data loss or processing lag.
  • Operational Costs: Emergency redeployments or crossAZ workarounds consume engineering time and may incur extra charges.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Hardware Failure: A hardware fault knocks out networking in AZA; all Lambda functions in that singleAZ VPC lose ENI attachment and fail to process inbound events.
  2. NAT Gateway Capacity Spike: A DDoS flood targets the NAT gateway in the lone AZ, saturating its throughput; VPCbound Lambdas cant reach the internet for API calls.
  3. Planned AZ Maintenance: AWS schedules maintenance that briefly disables ENI provisioning in AZB; because all subnets reside there, no new Lambda invocations succeed until maintenance completes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated runtime environments occur when Lambda functions continue using deprecated or unpatched language runtimes (e.g. old Node.js, Python, Java versions), missing security fixes and performance improvements.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning for known CVEs, supplychain adversaries embedding exploits in dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities in EOL runtimes.
    • Injecting malicious payloads through outdated library transitive dependencies.
    • Leveraging insecure default configurations tied to legacy runtimes.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers exploit CVEs to run arbitrary code in your functions.
  • Data Breach: Compromised functions expose sensitive input or environment data.
  • Service Disruption: Unpatched bugs cause function crashes or performance failures.
  • Compliance Risks: Use of unsupported runtimes may violate organizational or regulatory policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: A function running Python2.7 is targeted with a known bufferoverflow exploit, allowing an attacker to execute shell commands.
  2. Dependency Hijack: An outdated Node.js runtime pulls in a vulnerable version of a logging library; an attacker injects malicious code via crafted log messages.
  3. Misconfiguration Crash: A Java8 function uses an old JDBC driver with memoryleak bugs, causing repeated OOM errors and denial of service under load.

threat.name: Overly broad IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly broad IAM permissions occur when AWS Lambda execution roles or associated policies grant more privileges than necessaryoften using wildcards for actions or resourcesexposing your functions to escalate privileges or access unrelated services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised deployment pipelines, and external attackers using stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • IAM policies with "Action": "lambda:*" or "*" on "Resource": "*" attached to function roles.
    • Overpermissive trust relationships allowing any principal to assume the Lambda role.
    • Failure to apply leastprivilege when granting access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, IAM).

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Functions can call APIs beyond their scope (e.g., creating or deleting roles).
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive data from S3 buckets, databases, or Secrets Manager.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised functions pivot to other services or resources in your account.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended changes to infrastructure, such as spinning up expensive resources or deleting critical stacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Overreach: A Lambda role with s3:* on * is compromised; the attacker lists and downloads all buckets, harvesting PII.
  2. IAM Role Abuse: An overly broad iam:* permission lets a malicious function create a new admin user, granting full account control.
  3. Cost Shock: A function granted ec2:RunInstances and ec2:TerminateInstances is hijacked to spin up large fleets of instances, incurring massive charges and then deleting them to cover tracks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS Lambda occurs when the secrets, API keys, or IAM credentials used by functions are exposed or stoleneither through code, environment variables, or execution contextallowing attackers to impersonate or control your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, automated bots, thirdparty library leaks, compromised CI/CD pipelines
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Embedding secrets (AWS keys, database passwords) in function code or plaintext environment variables
    • Retrieving IAM role tokens from the Lambda execution environment via SSRF or metadataendpoint exploits
    • Exposing credentials in version control systems, build artifacts, or CloudWatch logs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Function Invocation: Attackers invoke functions at will, potentially incurring costs or executing unwanted actions
  • Privilege Escalation & Lateral Movement: Stolen credentials grant access to other AWS services or higherprivilege roles
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by Lambdas (e.g., PII, business logic) can be read or modified
  • Service Disruption & Financial Loss: Illicit use of credentials can flood queues, trigger throttling, or bill for large-scale invocations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hardcoded Key Leak: A developer commits a Lambda function with embedded AWS keys to GitHub. An attacker clones the repo, uses the keys to read S3 buckets, and exfiltrates customer data.
  2. Metadata Endpoint Abuse: A malicious library loaded into the Lambda execution environment makes HTTP calls to the IMDS endpoint, harvesting the functions IAM role token and using it to spin up new EC2 instances.
  3. Log Exposure: A misconfigured logging library prints database credentials from environment variables to CloudWatch Logs; a compromised IAM principal with logs:GetLogEvents reads the logs and uses the credentials to drop the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550.001 - Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions share flat or overly permissive network configurationssuch as residing in default VPC subnets without segmentation or securitygroup restrictionsthey gain unfettered access to internal systems and the internet, increasing risk of lateral movement and data exfiltration.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Compromised function code, malicious insiders, or thirdparty dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting broad VPC subnet placement to reach databases, caches, or internal APIs.
    • Using SSRF or openredirect flaws within the function to pivot across network boundaries.
    • Leveraging unrestricted egress to exfiltrate data to attackercontrolled endpoints.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Attackers breach internal resources (e.g., RDS, Redis) via the compromised functions network path.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive payloads or environment variables are sent out over the internet.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access to microservices, service meshes, or backend systems, undermining confidentiality and integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Database Pivot: A stolen function token is used to invoke a Lambda in the default VPC, which then connects to an internal MySQL cluster on port3306 to dump data.
  2. Internal Reconnaissance: An attacker injects SSRF payloads into a function endpoint, causing it to scan internal HTTP management interfaces and map out privileged services.
  3. Covert Exfiltration: A compromised dependency causes the function to upload decrypted S3 objects to an attackers external SFTP server, bypassing network ACLs.

threat.name: Lack of resource tagging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without consistent tagging, Lambda functions cant be programmatically identified for ownership, environment, or purposehindering cost tracking, security policy enforcement, and operational oversight.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, uncontrolled automation, and rogue deployments.
  • Vectors:
    • CI/CD pipelines creating functions without required Environment or Owner tags.
    • Manual console creations that omit security or compliance tags.
    • Thirdparty tooling that doesnt enforce tagging standards.

Impacts

  • Visibility Gaps: Security teams cant quickly locate or audit sensitive functions.
  • Policy Evasion: Tagbased IAM or GuardDuty suppression rules fail to apply, allowing unauthorized access.
  • Cost Overruns: Untracked orphan functions incur unexpected charges.
  • Cleanup Challenges: Hard to identify and decommission unused or outdated functions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hidden Malicious Function: An attacker deploys a backdoor Lambda without Team or Project tagsescaping routine audits and persisting undetected.
  2. Policy Bypass: A compromised automation role creates a function lacking the Compliance=PCI tag, sidestepping strict IAM permissions tied to that tag.
  3. Orphaned Resources: A deprecated services Lambdas remain untagged; months later, they still run and bill but arent owned or monitored by any team.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data exposure at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure at rest in AWS Lambda occurs when sensitive informationsuch as environment variables, function code packages, layers, or log snapshotsis stored unencrypted or with weak key management, making it accessible to unauthorized parties if storage systems are compromised.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised AWS credentials, and thirdparty service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Retrieving unencrypted Lambda environment variables or code bundles from S3/ECR.
    • Accessing /tmp storage on compromised execution hosts.
    • Downloading unencrypted CloudWatch log exports or Lambda layer artifacts.

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Exposed API keys, database passwords, or tokens.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atrest encryption mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA, GDPR).
  • Lateral Movement: Harvested credentials enable access to other AWS resources.
  • Reputational & Financial Damage: Data breach remediation costs and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. ECR Artifact Theft: An attacker with ECR read permissions pulls a Lambda image containing hardcoded secrets in its code, extracting them offline.
  2. S3 Snapshot Breach: Misconfigured S3 bucket hosts unencrypted function packages; adversaries download and inspect code to harvest environment variables.
  3. Log Export Exposure: A support engineer exports CloudWatch logs (including sensitive payloads) to an unencrypted S3 bucket, which is later accessed by unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data interception in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data interception in transit occurs when communication to or from Lambda functionssuch as API Gateway requests, servicetoservice calls, or event payloadsis sent without proper TLS or through misconfigured network paths, allowing adversaries to eavesdrop on or alter the data stream.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, maninthemiddle attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Invoking Lambda over HTTP (API Gateway or Function URL) instead of HTTPS
    • Misconfigured VPC endpoints or transit gateways that dont enforce encryption
    • Disabling or improperly validating TLS in SDKs or custom HTTP clients

Impacts

  • Credential Theft: API keys, JWTs, or signed URLs in request headers can be captured
  • Payload Exposure: Sensitive event data (PII, business logic) is readable in flight
  • Message Tampering: Intransit modification of inputs or outputs leads to corrupted processing
  • Replay Attacks: Captured invocations can be resent to trigger unauthorized function executions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. API Gateway Misuse: A functions URL endpoint is configured for HTTP only. An attacker on the same network sniffs request bodies containing user credentials and session tokens.
  2. VPC Endpoint Bypass: Lambda communicates with an internal service through a VPC endpoint that doesnt require TLS. A compromised EC2 instance in the VPC intercepts and logs unencrypted RPC calls.
  3. TLS Downgrade in SDK: A custom Python client disables certificate verification when calling a Lambda-backed API; an attacker performs a MITM attack to inject malicious payloads into the functions execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation via public resource policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive Lambda resource policies (e.g. "Principal": "*") expose functions to anyone on the internet or any AWS account, allowing unauthorized parties to invoke them without credentials.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised thirdparty accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Resourcebased policies granting lambda:InvokeFunction to Principal: "*".
    • Crossaccount policies missing Condition: {"StringEquals": {"AWS:SourceAccount": ...}}.
    • Automated scanners discovering public ARNs and issuing invoke requests.

Impacts

  • Unauthenticated Execution: Attackers trigger functions at will, potentially running malicious logic.
  • Cost Overruns: Highvolume invocations rack up unexpected AWS charges.
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Functions that read or write sensitive data can be abused to leak or corrupt information.
  • Downstream Disruption: Flooded event sources (queues, streams) or dependent services may be overwhelmed or fail.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Function Flood: An attacker discovers a public Lambda ARN and scripts thousands of InvokeFunction calls per minute, incurring heavy costs and throttling backend resources.
  2. CrossAccount Abuse: A partners account has open invocation rights; a malicious actor uses it to invoke a paymentprocessing Lambda with crafted payloads, creating fraudulent transactions.
  3. Data Leak via Unauthorized Payloads: A function tied to an S3 bucket runs on every invocation; by invoking it with custom payloads, an attacker tricks it into returning sensitive file contents in its response.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda API calls (e.g., CreateFunction, UpdateFunctionCode, InvokeFunction) arent captured by CloudTrail or centralized logging, unauthorized or malicious activity goes unrecorded.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious insiders or compromised roles making API calls
  • Automated tools invoking or updating functions without generating logs
  • Misconfigured CloudTrail trails or logdelivery failures

Impacts

  • Undetected Changes: Function code or configuration modifications arent noticed
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cant be reconstructed or attributed
  • Compliance Failures: Violation of auditlogging mandates (e.g., PCIDSS, HIPAA)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker updates a paymentprocessing Lambda to include malicious logic; without CloudTrail logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A rogue script purges function versions via the SDK; absent audit entries, the deletions go unnoticed until failures occur.
  3. CloudTrail misconfiguration drops InvokeFunction records; a compromised role invokes backdoor functions repeatedly without alerting security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Bootstrap backdoor persistence in custom runtimes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Custom runtimes in AWS Lambda rely on a 'bootstrap' file as their entry point, executed before reaching the handler. Without proper monitoring, this file can be manipulated to include malicious logic, enabling persistence across deployments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to deployment processes can modify the 'bootstrap' file to execute unauthorized activities, such as exfiltrating data, establishing backdoors, or altering runtime functionality.
Impacts
The compromise of the 'bootstrap' file can lead to unauthorized data access, persistent backdoors in the runtime environment, and stealthy modifications that evade detection during typical security reviews.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker with deployment privileges embeds malicious code into the 'bootstrap' file that exfiltrates sensitive data to an external server. Despite subsequent changes to the main handler logic, the hidden backdoor remains operational, continuing its activity undetected across multiple deployments.

reference.name: Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor (July 11, 2025)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

threat.name: Code integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Malicious alteration of Lambda function code or its dependenciesvia compromised build pipelines, direct edits, or tainted layersinjects unauthorized logic into your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems, supplychain attackers
  • Vectors: Backdoored build artifacts, console/API code edits, inclusion of malicious Lambda layers

Impacts

  • Unauthorized code execution under your functions IAM role
  • Data exfiltration or tampering of event payloads and backend resources
  • Lateral movement via calls to other AWS services
  • Reputational harm and remediation costs

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CI/CD Injection: An attacker hijacks the build server to insert a reverseshell payload into the deployment ZIP.
  2. Console Swap: A compromised admin replaces production handler code via the AWS Console, embedding dataexfiltration logic.
  3. Malicious Layer: A popular thirdparty layer bundles a cryptominer, which executes under your account when included.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Design for high availability and automatic failover using AWS regions and availability zones
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure your applications and databases use AWS Regions and Availability Zones (AZs) for high availability and automatic failover. Follow these steps:

  1. Select Regions and AZs: Choose regions and AZs that meet your requirements for latency, compliance, and availability.
  2. Deploy Redundantly: Distribute application servers and databases across multiple AZs.
  3. Load Balancing: Use Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) to distribute traffic across instances in different AZs.
  4. Database Failover: Enable automatic failover for databases using Amazon RDS or Aurora with Multi-AZ deployment.
  5. Auto Scaling: Configure Auto Scaling groups to maintain healthy instance counts across AZs.
  6. Cross-Region Replication: Implement cross-region replication for critical applications.
  7. Monitor and Test: Regularly test failover mechanisms and use AWS CloudWatch for monitoring.
  8. DNS Failover: Use Amazon Route 53 with health checks for DNS failover.

standard.ref: Business Continuity Management and Operational Resilience
DE.AE-3: Event data are collected and correlated from multiple sources and sensors
DE.AE-4: Impact of events is determined
ID.AM-5: Resources (e.g., hardware, devices, data, time, personnel, and software) are prioritized based on their classification, criticality, and business value
ID.AM-6: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established
ID.BE-4: Dependencies and critical functions for delivery of critical services are established
ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.RA-4: Potential business impacts and likelihoods are identified
ID.SC-5: Response and recovery planning and testing are conducted with suppliers and third-party providers
PR.AT-5: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.IP-10: Response and recovery plans are tested
PR.IP-4: Backups of information are conducted, maintained, and tested
PR.IP-8: Effectiveness of protection technologies is shared
PR.IP-9: Response plans (Incident Response and Business Continuity) and recovery plans (Incident Recovery and Disaster Recovery) are in place and managed
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
PR.PT-5: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
RC.CO-3: Recovery activities are communicated to internal and external stakeholders as well as executive and management teams
RC.IM-1: Recovery plans incorporate lessons learned
RC.RP-1: Recovery plan is executed during or after a cybersecurity incident
RS.AN-2: The impact of the incident is understood
RS.AN-4: Incidents are categorized consistent with response plans
RS.CO-1: Personnel know their roles and order of operations when a response is needed
RS.CO-3: Information is shared consistent with response plans
RS.CO-4: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans
RS.IM-1: Response plans incorporate lessons learned
RS.RP-1: Response plan is executed during or after an incident

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail logging for AWS Organizations API calls
countermeasure.desc:
Set up AWS CloudTrail to log all API calls to AWS Organizations to track and audit user activities, aiding in the detection and response to unauthorized actions. Follow these steps:

Create a Trail:

  • Open the AWS CloudTrail console.
  • Select "Trails" and click "Create trail."
  • Name the trail and apply it to all regions.

Configure Logging:

  • Enable "Management events" for read and write operations.
  • Include AWS Organizations as an event source.

Specify an S3 Bucket:

  • Choose or create an S3 bucket for log storage.
  • Configure permissions and enable encryption.

Enable Log Validation:

  • Activate log file validation for integrity.

Integrate with CloudWatch:

  • Send logs to CloudWatch Logs.
  • Set up log groups and CloudWatch alarms for specific events.

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for cross-account permissions in AWS Organizations
countermeasure.desc:
Assign permissions to users or groups in the management account and use IAM roles to grant AWS Organizations permissions for users in member accounts. Follow these steps:

Assign Permissions in the Management Account:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the IAM service.
  • Create or select IAM users/groups and assign necessary permissions for AWS Organizations.

Create IAM Roles in Member Accounts:

  • In each member account, create IAM roles that specify trusted entities (the management account).
  • Attach policies to these roles to define the allowed actions within the member account.

Establish Trust Relationships:

  • Edit the trust relationship of the IAM roles in member accounts to trust the management account.

Grant Access Using IAM Roles:

  • From the management account, use the sts:AssumeRole API to grant users/groups access to the member accounts via the created IAM roles.

Test Access:

  • Verify that users/groups in the management account can assume roles and perform actions in member accounts as per assigned permissions.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

countermeasure.name: Use VPC endpoints with AWS PrivateLink for AWS Organizations access
countermeasure.desc:
Set up VPC endpoints with AWS PrivateLink to access AWS Organizations securely within your VPC without using the public internet. Follow these steps:

Create a VPC Endpoint:

  • Open the Amazon VPC console.
  • Go to "Endpoints" and click "Create Endpoint."
  • Select "com.amazonaws.<region>.organizations" and choose your VPC.

Configure Endpoint Settings:

  • Choose subnets and security groups.
  • Enable "Private DNS Name" for standard DNS within your VPC.

Set Endpoint Policies:

  • Attach a policy to control access.

Update Security Groups:

  • Allow traffic to/from the VPC endpoint.

Test Configuration:

  • Verify AWS Organizations access through the endpoint.
  • Ensure external access fails.

countermeasure.name: Utilize AWS Config and Security Hub for compliance and security monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Use AWS Config to assess resource configurations against compliance requirements and AWS Security Hub to obtain a comprehensive view of your security state and compliance status. Follow these steps:

Set Up AWS Config:

  • Open the AWS Config console.
  • Click "Get started" and select the resources to be recorded.
  • Create configuration rules to check compliance against your standards (e.g., CIS, NIST).

Enable AWS Security Hub:

  • Open the AWS Security Hub console.
  • Click "Enable Security Hub" to start aggregating security findings.
  • Integrate with AWS Config to pull in compliance data.

Configure Compliance Rules:

  • Define custom compliance rules in AWS Config to match your organization's policies.
  • Use managed rules available in AWS Config for common compliance frameworks.

Review and Analyze Findings:

  • Regularly review compliance findings in AWS Config.
  • Use AWS Security Hub to analyze and prioritize security alerts and compliance status.
  • Enable automatic remediation actions in AWS Config where possible.

Generate Reports and Alerts:

  • Set up AWS Config to generate periodic compliance reports.
  • Configure AWS Security Hub to send alerts for critical issues to SNS, email, or other notification services.

reference.name: Evaluating Resources with AWS Config Rules

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Insufficient resilience planning
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Insufficient resilience planning refers to the lack of strategies to ensure AWS Organizations can withstand and recover from disruptions, such as outages, disasters, or attacks, resulting in prolonged downtime and data loss.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Natural Disasters: Earthquakes, floods, hurricanes.
  • Cyber Attacks: DDoS, ransomware, hacking.
  • Human Error: Misconfigurations, accidental deletions.
  • Hardware/Software Failures: Malfunctions, bugs.

Impacts

  • Operational Disruption: Downtime and halted business operations.
  • Data Loss: Permanent loss of critical data.
  • Financial Loss: Revenue loss and recovery costs.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and regulatory penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Natural Disaster: Earthquake disrupts primary data center; lack of multi-AZ deployment leads to downtime and data loss.
  2. DDoS Attack: Overwhelms network infrastructure; absence of auto-scaling causes extended outages.
  3. Ransomware Attack: Encrypts critical data; inadequate backup prevents quick recovery.
  4. Human Error: Accidental deletion of AWS resource; delayed restoration due to missing backups.

By implementing multi-AZ deployments, robust backup strategies, and automated failover mechanisms, organizations can mitigate risks associated with insufficient resilience planning.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insufficient access control management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Insufficient access control management occurs when there are inadequate policies and mechanisms to control and monitor access to AWS Organizations resources. This can lead to unauthorized access and misuse of sensitive information and resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting weak access controls.
  • Insider Threats: Employees misusing their access rights.
  • Misconfigured Access Policies: Incorrectly set permissions or roles.
  • Compromised Credentials: Stolen or leaked access keys and passwords.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Unauthorized individuals gain access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Data Breach: Leakage of confidential information.
  • Operational Disruption: Misuse of resources causing service disruptions.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with data breaches and recovery.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust and credibility.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: Hacker exploits weak IAM policies to access AWS Organizations resources.
  2. Insider Misuse: Employee with excessive permissions misuses access to alter configurations.
  3. Misconfigured Roles: Incorrectly configured IAM roles grant broader access than intended, leading to unauthorized actions.
  4. Stolen Credentials: Attacker uses compromised credentials to perform unauthorized actions.

Implementing strict access controls, regularly auditing permissions, and using IAM roles effectively can mitigate risks associated with insufficient access control management.

threat.name: Inadequate network access controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Inadequate network access controls occur when there are insufficient mechanisms to restrict and monitor network traffic to and from AWS Organizations. This can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and potential exploitation of network vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting weak network security configurations.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with unauthorized network access.
  • Misconfigured Network Settings: Incorrectly configured security groups, network ACLs, or VPC settings.
  • Unsecured Communication Channels: Lack of encryption or secure connections for network traffic.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Operational Disruption: Network attacks causing service interruptions.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with data breaches, service disruptions, and recovery efforts.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust and credibility due to compromised network security.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties due to failure to meet data protection and security standards.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Security Groups: An attacker exploits open security groups allowing unrestricted access to AWS Organizations resources.
  2. Insider Access Abuse: An employee with broad network access misuses their privileges to access sensitive information.
  3. Misconfigured VPC: Misconfigured VPC settings lead to unintended exposure of resources to the public internet.
  4. Unsecured API Calls: Lack of encryption for API calls allows attackers to intercept and manipulate data in transit.

Implementing strict network access controls, such as VPC endpoints, security groups, and network ACLs, along with monitoring and encrypting network traffic, can significantly mitigate the risks associated with inadequate network access controls.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Unmonitored administrative actions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unmonitored administrative actions refer to the absence of logging, monitoring, and auditing of actions performed by administrators in AWS Organizations. This can lead to undetected unauthorized changes, misconfigurations, or malicious activities, compromising the security and integrity of the AWS environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Threats: Employees or contractors with administrative access making unauthorized changes.
  • External Attackers: Hackers gaining administrative access through compromised credentials.
  • Misconfigurations: Unintended changes due to lack of oversight and monitoring.
  • Lack of Audit Trails: Absence of detailed logs to track administrative actions.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized changes leading to exposure of sensitive data.
  • Operational Disruption: Service interruptions due to unmonitored and potentially harmful changes.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with rectifying unauthorized actions and potential fines.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders due to security incidents.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to meet compliance requirements for auditing and monitoring.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An external attacker uses stolen administrative credentials to make unauthorized changes, such as altering IAM policies, without being detected.
  2. Malicious Insider: An employee with administrative privileges makes unauthorized changes to configurations and resources, causing data leakage and operational issues.
  3. Untracked Configurations: Changes to critical configurations go unnoticed due to lack of monitoring, leading to security vulnerabilities and potential exploits.
  4. Audit Failures: During a compliance audit, it is discovered that there are no logs or monitoring of administrative actions, resulting in regulatory penalties.

Implementing comprehensive logging and monitoring using tools such as AWS CloudTrail, AWS Config, and AWS Security Hub can help detect and respond to unauthorized administrative actions promptly.

threat.name: Lack of compliance validation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Lack of compliance validation occurs when there are no mechanisms in place to ensure that AWS Organizations and its resources comply with industry standards, regulatory requirements, and internal policies. This oversight can lead to unintentional non-compliance, resulting in legal and financial repercussions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Auditors: Inadequate internal auditing processes.
  • External Regulators: Failure to meet external regulatory standards.
  • System Misconfigurations: Incorrectly configured resources that do not adhere to compliance requirements.
  • Lack of Automated Compliance Checks: Absence of tools to automatically validate compliance.

Impacts

  • Legal Penalties: Fines and sanctions due to non-compliance with regulations such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI DSS.
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with rectifying compliance issues and potential fines.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust and business opportunities due to non-compliance.
  • Operational Disruption: Disruption in services to address compliance failures and implement corrective measures.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Failed Audit: An organization undergoes an external audit and fails to meet compliance requirements due to a lack of proper validation mechanisms.
  2. Regulatory Fines: Failure to comply with data protection regulations like GDPR results in significant fines and legal actions.
  3. Data Breach: Non-compliance with security standards leads to a data breach, exposing sensitive customer information and resulting in legal penalties.
  4. Unidentified Misconfigurations: An organization unknowingly runs misconfigured resources that violate compliance policies, leading to operational and financial consequences when discovered.

Implementing regular compliance validation through automated tools like AWS Config, AWS Audit Manager, and AWS Security Hub can help ensure continuous compliance with industry standards and regulations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1063 - Security Software Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-1188
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1188: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

weakness.name: CWE-16
weakness.desc: CWE:

weakness.name: CWE-209
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-308 CWE-307
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required. CWE-307: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts The product does not implement sufficient measures to prevent multiple failed authentication attempts within a short time frame, making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319 CWE-352
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-614 CWE-613
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-614: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without 'Secure' Attribute The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.
CWE-613: Insufficient Session Expiration According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-778 CWE-117
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.
CWE-117: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

weakness.name: CWE-79 CWE-20
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.
CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Automated configuration management tools
countermeasure.desc:
Automated configuration management tools help maintain system configurations in a desired, secure state. These tools can automate the setup, deployment, and maintenance of software across various environments, ensuring that configurations are consistent and aligned with security best practices. Heres how to implement these tools for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Choose a Configuration Management Tool

  • Select a tool that suits your environment and needs. Popular options include Ansible, Chef, Puppet, and SaltStack. Consider factors such as ease of use, community support, and compatibility with your existing stack.

Step 2: Define Secure Configuration Baselines

  • Develop configuration baselines that comply with security best practices. This might include setting password policies, configuring role-based access controls, and disabling unnecessary services.
  • Utilize security benchmarks from organizations like the Center for Internet Security (CIS) as references for configuring security settings.

Step 3: Automate Configuration Scripts

  • Write scripts or 'playbooks' (in Ansible) to automate the deployment and configuration of the Account software component. Ensure these scripts enforce the security baselines.
  • Include tasks that check for default settings and change them, install necessary security updates, and configure firewalls or other security controls.

Step 4: Integrate Configuration Management in the Deployment Pipeline

  • Integrate your configuration management tool into your continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipeline. This ensures that every deployment is automatically configured to the defined security standards.
  • Use the tool to automatically apply configurations during both initial setup and subsequent deployments to maintain consistency.

Step 5: Regularly Update and Review Configuration Scripts

  • Regularly review and update your configuration scripts to adapt to new security threats and compliance requirements.
  • Use version control to manage changes in your configuration scripts. This provides an audit trail for changes and helps in troubleshooting.

Step 6: Monitor and Audit Configurations

  • Set up monitoring within your configuration management tool to track and report deviations from the defined configuration baselines.
  • Regularly audit your environment using the tool to ensure compliance with the security policies and to detect any unauthorized changes.

Step 7: Educate Your Team

  • Provide training and resources to your development and operations teams about the importance of security through consistent configurations and how to use the configuration management tool effectively.

Further Considerations:

  • Security as Code: Treat your security configurations and scripts as code. This approach aligns with the infrastructure as code (IaC) philosophy, promoting consistency and ease of management.
  • Documentation: Document your configuration management practices and keep this documentation updated. This helps new team members understand your security infrastructure and contributes to better security hygiene.

By following these steps and regularly updating your configurations in response to emerging threats, you can significantly enhance the security and consistency of your software environments.

countermeasure.name: Data handling best practices
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing data handling best practices helps safeguard sensitive information throughout its lifecycle to prevent unauthorized access, leaks, and data breaches. Here's how to apply these practices for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Identify and Classify Data

  • Inventory all data types handled, distinguishing personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, or other sensitive information.
  • Classify data based on sensitivity, such as public, internal, confidential, and highly confidential.

Step 2: Apply Data Encryption

  • At Rest: Encrypt sensitive data at rest using strong encryption algorithms like AES-256.
    • Use a dedicated encryption library or service (e.g., AWS KMS, HashiCorp Vault) to manage encryption keys securely.
  • In Transit: Enforce encryption for data in transit using TLS 1.2+ or equivalent for all network communication.

Step 3: Implement Access Controls

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Grant data access based on user roles, ensuring that only authorized individuals can view or modify sensitive information.
  • Principle of Least Privilege: Apply the minimum permissions required for each user or service account.
  • Separation of Duties: Divide access privileges among different roles to minimize insider threats.

Step 4: Secure Data Storage

  • Sanitize sensitive data before storage, stripping out unnecessary information.
  • Mask or anonymize data in non-production environments like development and testing.
  • Store data in secure locations and restrict direct access to storage systems.

Step 5: Logging and Monitoring

  • Log data access and modification activities for sensitive information.
  • Monitor logs for unusual access patterns or unauthorized attempts.

Step 6: Data Retention and Disposal

  • Define and enforce data retention policies to retain data only as long as needed.
  • Safely dispose of sensitive data by securely wiping files or physically destroying storage media.

Step 7: Regular Audits and Reviews

  • Periodically review data handling practices to ensure compliance with relevant regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA).
  • Conduct security audits and penetration testing to detect vulnerabilities in data protection measures.

Step 8: Educate and Train Staff

  • Train developers, system administrators, and other staff members in data protection principles, including data minimization and secure coding practices.
  • Emphasize the importance of secure data handling throughout the development process.

Further Considerations:

  • Regulatory Compliance: Be aware of industry-specific data protection regulations and integrate those requirements into your data handling processes.
  • Backup and Recovery: Ensure that data backups are encrypted, securely stored, and tested for disaster recovery.

By following these best practices, you ensure that sensitive account data is properly handled and protected against internal and external threats.

countermeasure.name: Enforce anti-CSRF measures
countermeasure.desc:
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks trick authenticated users into performing unintended actions on a web application. Enforcing anti-CSRF measures ensures that your web application processes only legitimate, authorized requests. Here's how to implement these measures for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Use Synchronizer Tokens

  • Token Generation:
    • Generate a unique, unpredictable CSRF token for each user session or form. Libraries like csurf (Node.js), django.middleware.csrf (Django), or Spring Security CSRF (Java) can simplify this.
  • Token Insertion:
    • Embed the generated token in all forms that modify state (e.g., POST, PUT, DELETE requests).
    • For APIs, include tokens in custom headers rather than as URL parameters.
  • Token Verification:
    • Verify the CSRF token on the server for each incoming request. Reject requests missing a valid token.

Step 2: Use SameSite Cookies

  • Set the SameSite attribute for cookies to Strict or Lax to prevent cookies from being sent in cross-site requests.
    • Example for secure cookies:

Set-Cookie: sessionid=<session_id>; Secure; HttpOnly; SameSite=Strict
Step 3: Implement Referrer Header Checks

  • For sensitive actions, validate that the Referrer header matches the application's origin or domain.
  • Reject requests with an empty or mismatched Referrer header.

Step 4: Require Re-Authentication for Critical Actions

  • For critical actions like changing passwords or transferring funds, ask users to re-enter their credentials or use multi-factor authentication.

Step 5: Educate Users on Phishing Attacks

  • Provide security education to end-users, warning them about the risks of phishing emails and malicious links that could facilitate CSRF.

Step 6: Regularly Test CSRF Defenses

  • Conduct security testing, including manual tests and automated security tools, to validate that anti-CSRF measures are working effectively.

Further Considerations:

  • Framework-Specific Defenses: Leverage built-in CSRF protection if available in your web framework (e.g., Rails, ASP.NET MVC).
  • Whitelist IPs: Consider restricting sensitive actions to specific trusted IP addresses if feasible.

By following these steps and staying updated on new CSRF vulnerabilities, you can ensure your web application remains secure against these attacks.

standard.ref: Cross-Site Request Forgery Prevention Cheat Sheet
Insecure Direct Object Reference Prevention Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive encryption strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Comprehensive encryption strategies protect sensitive data at rest and in transit using strong encryption algorithms. This helps prevent unauthorized access, ensuring data confidentiality and integrity throughout its lifecycle. Here's how to implement these strategies for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Classify and Identify Sensitive Data

  • Identify sensitive information, such as user credentials, personal identification numbers, and financial data, and classify it based on sensitivity (e.g., PII, confidential).

Step 2: Encrypt Data at Rest

  • Databases and Storage Systems:
    • Apply encryption for sensitive data stored in databases using strong algorithms like AES-256.
    • Use database encryption features, third-party tools, or file-level encryption.
  • File Storage:
    • Encrypt files containing sensitive information using standard encryption tools (e.g., OpenSSL, GPG).
    • Consider encrypting entire storage volumes (e.g., using BitLocker or LUKS).
  • Encryption Key Management:
    • Implement a secure encryption key management system. Use hardware security modules (HSMs) or dedicated key management services (e.g., AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault).
    • Rotate encryption keys regularly and ensure keys are stored securely, separate from encrypted data.

Step 3: Encrypt Data in Transit

  • Network Communication:
    • Use TLS 1.2+ for all communication between clients and servers. Obtain certificates from a trusted certificate authority.
    • Set up strict transport security policies (HSTS) to enforce secure connections.
  • API and Service Communication:
    • Apply mutual TLS (mTLS) for service-to-service communication to verify both parties' identities.
    • Avoid insecure protocols like FTP and HTTP.

Step 4: Encrypt Backups

  • Encrypt backup files, whether stored on-site or off-site, to ensure data remains protected in case of unauthorized access.
  • Follow the same encryption and key management standards as for primary storage.

Step 5: Secure Cryptographic Operations

  • Algorithms and Libraries:
    • Use industry-standard cryptographic algorithms and libraries (e.g., OpenSSL, BouncyCastle).
    • Avoid outdated algorithms like MD5 or SHA-1.
  • Configuration:
    • Ensure encryption parameters like salt, initialization vector (IV), and key sizes meet current best practices.

Step 6: Test Encryption Implementation

  • Regularly test the encryption implementation for proper configuration and possible vulnerabilities using security tools and penetration testing.

Step 7: Educate Teams on Encryption Usage

  • Train development teams to identify sensitive data and apply encryption practices.
  • Promote secure encryption usage in coding, key management, and protocol selection.

By following these comprehensive steps, you can ensure that sensitive data related to the "Account" software component is protected, reducing the risk of data breaches and unauthorized access.

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive input validation and aanitization
countermeasure.desc:
Comprehensive input validation and sanitization ensure that user input is processed securely to prevent injection attacks, buffer overflows, and other vulnerabilities. Heres how to implement it for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Identify All Input Sources

  • Locate all input points, including form fields, query parameters, API endpoints, file uploads, and cookies.
  • Note internal sources like inter-service communication and system environment variables.

Step 2: Define Input Validation Rules

  • Establish validation rules for each input type:
    • Text Fields: Set length limits, restrict characters to allowed sets (e.g., letters, numbers), and disallow dangerous characters (e.g., <, >).
    • Numeric Fields: Verify the data type, minimum and maximum values.
    • Date/Time Fields: Ensure the date/time values are in the correct format and logical range.
    • Files: Limit the allowed file types, and check the file size.
    • Emails/URLs: Use regular expressions to enforce standard formatting.

Step 3: Implement Input Validation Logic

  • Use server-side validation for all inputs:
    • Apply programming language-specific libraries or frameworks for validation (e.g., express-validator for Node.js, validator.js).
    • Handle validation errors gracefully by returning informative error messages to the client.
  • For client-side validation:
    • Use built-in browser validation mechanisms or JavaScript frameworks for improved user experience.
    • Note that client-side validation should never replace server-side validation.

Step 4: Sanitize Inputs

  • Remove or encode potentially dangerous characters using appropriate libraries:
    • For text fields, escape special characters like < and >.
    • For file uploads, sanitize file names and paths to remove control characters or directory traversal attempts.
    • Use parameterized queries for SQL statements or prepared statements to prevent SQL injection.

Step 5: Secure API Endpoints

  • Ensure that APIs enforce input validation and sanitization as rigorously as web forms.
  • Reject malformed requests with detailed error messages while avoiding information leakage.

Step 6: Test and Monitor Input Validation Mechanisms

  • Perform regular security testing, including fuzz testing, to identify potential validation weaknesses.
  • Monitor logs and alerts for unusual activity that might indicate an attempted attack.

Step 7: Educate Development Teams

  • Train developers to recognize injection risks and apply secure coding practices in their daily work.

Further Considerations:

  • Security Frameworks: Leverage application security frameworks like OWASPs ESAPI or web application firewall (WAF) rules for centralized input validation and sanitization.
  • Regular Updates: Keep all validation libraries updated to avoid relying on deprecated or vulnerable methods.

By enforcing these practices, you can prevent malicious inputs from compromising the integrity and security of the Account software component.

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Comprehensive logging and monitoring help identify security incidents, troubleshoot system issues, and track user behavior. Proper logging and monitoring help ensure visibility across the "Account" software component. Heres how to implement these measures:

Step 1: Identify Critical Events to Log

  • Authentication: Log successful and failed login attempts, password changes, and session terminations.
  • Authorization: Record when users or services access sensitive data or perform privileged actions.
  • Configuration Changes: Track changes to user roles, permissions, application settings, or security policies.
  • Data Access and Modification: Monitor read, write, delete, or update operations on critical data.
  • Error Logs: Capture application errors and exceptions to identify potential vulnerabilities.

Step 2: Implement Centralized Logging

  • Logging Framework: Choose a reliable logging framework (e.g., log4j, Serilog, Winston) for your programming environment.
  • Log Format: Use consistent, structured formats like JSON or plain text with delimiters for log data.
  • Log Aggregation: Aggregate logs into a central repository using a solution like the ELK Stack, Splunk, or Fluentd to facilitate analysis.

Step 3: Protect Log Integrity and Confidentiality

  • Restrict access to logs, allowing only authorized personnel to view and modify them.
  • Encrypt sensitive log data, particularly when logs contain personal information or access credentials.
  • Enable immutability features or use tamper-evident storage for critical logs.

Step 4: Set Up Real-Time Monitoring and Alerts

  • Alert Criteria: Define criteria for suspicious activity (e.g., repeated failed logins, unauthorized data access) to trigger alerts.
  • Alerting Tools: Use Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems to automate monitoring and alerts.
  • Notifications: Send alerts to security teams via email, SMS, or ticketing systems.

Step 5: Implement Log Retention Policies

  • Retain logs for an appropriate period based on compliance, regulatory, and business requirements.
  • Archive older logs to cheaper storage or delete them securely after the retention period.

Step 6: Regularly Review Logs and Audit Security Policies

  • Analyze log data periodically to identify trends and potential weaknesses.
  • Conduct manual or automated audits to verify that logs are generated and retained per security policies.

Step 7: Train Staff in Log Management

  • Educate the development and security teams on how to manage, analyze, and interpret logs for improved incident response.

By following these steps, you can ensure comprehensive logging and monitoring practices that provide high visibility, enhance security, and help identify potential issues in the "Account" software component.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Computer Security Log Management
