countermeasure.name: Implement content security policy (CSP)
countermeasure.desc:
A Content Security Policy (CSP) helps prevent cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks, clickjacking, and other code injection vulnerabilities by specifying allowed content sources for web pages. Heres how to implement a CSP for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Define the CSP Policy

  • Self-Hosted Content: Only allow content loaded from your own domains and subdomains (self directive).
  • Third-Party Content: Restrict third-party content, such as scripts, images, and styles, by specifying trusted external sources.
  • Inline Scripts and Styles: Avoid inline scripts and styles wherever possible. If required, allow them using hashes or nonces.
  • Form Actions: Limit form submission URLs to trusted domains.
  • Other Resources: Explicitly control sources for frames, fonts, media, and objects.

Step 2: Write the CSP Header

  • Create a CSP policy using the appropriate directives:

Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'nonce-xyz'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; img-src 'self' data:

  • Common directives:
    • default-src: Fallback for other directives.
    • script-src: Sources for JavaScript.
    • style-src: Sources for CSS.
    • img-src: Sources for images.
    • font-src: Sources for fonts.
    • frame-ancestors: Limits embedding in iframes.
    • form-action: Limits form submission URLs.
  • Set report-uri or report-to to log violations without breaking the application.

Step 3: Apply the CSP Header

  • HTTP Headers: Send the Content-Security-Policy header in all HTTP responses, either through server configurations (Apache/Nginx) or web framework settings.
  • Meta Tags: As a fallback or complement, include <meta> tags in HTML <head> sections to apply the CSP policy.

Step 4: Test and Refine the Policy

  • Report-Only Mode: Initially use Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only to identify blocked content without enforcing restrictions.
  • Violation Reports: Review violation reports to refine the policy. Adjust directives until no false positives occur.
  • Enforcement Mode: Switch to Content-Security-Policy to enforce the CSP once the policy is stable.

Step 5: Regularly Monitor and Update CSP Policies

  • Monitor for CSP violations and new security vulnerabilities that might affect your web app.
  • Update the CSP policy regularly to keep up with changes in allowed content sources.

Best Practices:

  • Avoid 'unsafe-inline' and 'unsafe-eval' in production policies to minimize risk.
  • Consider nonces or hashes over 'unsafe-inline' to allow trusted inline scripts or styles securely.
  • Keep your CSP policy as strict as possible while still allowing necessary functionality.

By following these steps, you can implement a secure CSP that helps mitigate a wide range of attacks targeting your web content.

countermeasure.name: Implement custom error handling and generic messaging
countermeasure.desc:
Custom error handling and generic messaging ensure that sensitive information is not exposed in error messages. They also provide useful feedback to users while protecting the "Account" software component from information disclosure attacks. Heres how to implement it effectively:

Step 1: Define Standardized Error Responses

  • User-Friendly Messages: Develop clear, concise, non-technical error messages for users to indicate the nature of errors (e.g., "Invalid username or password").
  • Error Codes: Assign unique, non-sequential error codes for different types of errors. These can be used for tracking and troubleshooting.

Step 2: Implement a Centralized Error Handling Mechanism

  • Global Exception Handler: Set up a global error handler or middleware to capture unhandled exceptions.
    • In web frameworks like Express (Node.js) or Django, this could be a dedicated middleware layer.
    • In other environments, configure a top-level error handler or a global try-catch structure.
  • Log Errors Securely:
    • Record full error details in server logs for analysis.
    • Ensure logs are secure and access-controlled to authorized personnel only.

Step 3: Provide Consistent User Messaging

  • Client-Facing Errors: Ensure errors displayed to end-users are generic and reveal minimal technical details.
    • Avoid revealing implementation specifics, such as internal paths, stack traces, or configuration settings.
    • Provide helpful, generic messages (e.g., "An unexpected error occurred. Please try again or contact support.")
  • Back-End Services: For API responses, use standard HTTP error codes (e.g., 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized) and return generic messages.

Step 4: Handle Different Error Types Appropriately

  • Input Validation Errors: Provide specific feedback to users on why input validation failed without revealing validation logic.
  • Authentication and Authorization Errors: Return generic messages (e.g., "Invalid credentials") for failed logins to avoid exposing valid usernames.
  • Application-Level Errors: Handle internal server errors gracefully to prevent leaking system information.

Step 5: Monitor and Audit Error Trends

  • Monitor errors regularly to detect abnormal patterns or potential security issues (e.g., brute-force attacks).
  • Conduct audits to ensure that error-handling mechanisms conform to security best practices.

Further Considerations:

  • Localization and Accessibility: If your application is multilingual, localize error messages to provide clarity. Ensure messages are accessible.
  • Compliance: Ensure error logging and handling comply with data protection and security standards like GDPR, HIPAA, etc.

By following these steps, you can enhance the security and user experience of the "Account" software component, while ensuring sensitive information remains protected.

countermeasure.name: Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) enhances account security by requiring additional verification factors, making it more difficult for unauthorized parties to access an account even if login credentials are compromised. Here's how to implement it for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Define MFA Policy

  • Determine which user roles and actions require MFA (e.g., all users, admins only, sensitive operations).
  • Decide which factors to use (e.g., OTP via SMS, TOTP apps, security keys, biometrics).

Step 2: Implement First-Factor Authentication

  • Verify the primary authentication factor, typically the username-password combination, using secure practices:
    • Enforce strong password policies.
    • Hash passwords securely using algorithms like bcrypt or Argon2.

Step 3: Choose a Secondary Authentication Method

  • Time-Based One-Time Password (TOTP):
    • Integrate TOTP apps like Google Authenticator or Authy.
    • Use libraries like pyotp (Python), otpauth (Node.js), or Otp.NET (C#) for token generation and validation.
  • SMS-Based OTP:
    • Generate and send OTPs via a secure SMS provider (e.g., Twilio).
    • Ensure OTPs expire within a short time.
  • Email-Based OTP:
    • Send OTPs to a verified email address with similar expiry rules as SMS.
  • Hardware Tokens/Security Keys:
    • Support Universal 2nd Factor (U2F) tokens, such as YubiKey.
    • Ensure that server endpoints are U2F-compatible.

Step 4: Implement Verification Workflow

  • Registration:
    • Allow users to register their secondary authentication method via a secure process.
    • Provide backup codes as an alternative if they lose access to the secondary factor.
  • Authentication Flow:
    • After the first-factor login, prompt users to provide the secondary factor.
    • Validate the submitted token against stored data or external services.
    • Deny access if the secondary factor is incorrect or expired.

Step 5: Enhance User Experience

  • Recovery Options:
    • Provide secure recovery mechanisms (e.g., backup codes, email-based recovery) for users who lose their secondary factor.
  • Device Trusting:
    • Optionally allow users to trust devices for a certain period (e.g., 30 days) after a successful MFA login.

Step 6: Monitor and Log MFA Attempts

  • Monitor MFA attempts and flag unusual patterns (e.g., repeated failures) to detect potential attacks.
  • Log successful and failed MFA attempts for auditing purposes.

Further Considerations:

  • Accessibility: Ensure MFA methods are accessible and don't exclude users due to physical limitations or lack of technical resources.
  • Regulatory Compliance: Follow regulatory requirements for MFA implementation, such as PCI DSS or HIPAA.

Implementing these steps will significantly increase account security and reduce the risk of unauthorized access in the "Account" software component.

countermeasure.name: Implement prepared statements and parameterized queries
countermeasure.desc:
Prepared statements and parameterized queries are essential for preventing SQL injection attacks by separating SQL code from data inputs. Here's how to implement these security features effectively in the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Choose a Database API Supporting Prepared Statements

  • Ensure that the database API or library used in your programming environment supports prepared statements (e.g., PDO for PHP, mysql-connector-python, Java's JDBC, etc.).

Step 2: Replace Inline SQL Queries

  • Identify all instances where inline SQL queries or user inputs are used directly within queries.
  • Replace each of these queries with prepared statements.

Step 3: Use Parameterized Queries for Data Inputs

  • For every SQL query, use placeholders (? or named parameters) instead of concatenating user-provided input directly into the query.
  • Bind user inputs securely to these placeholders through parameters.

Example:

Java (JDBC):

String query = "SELECT * FROM accounts WHERE username = ? AND password = ?";
PreparedStatement stmt = connection.prepareStatement(query);
stmt.setString(1, username);
stmt.setString(2, password);
ResultSet rs = stmt.executeQuery();

Python (MySQL Connector):
query = "SELECT * FROM accounts WHERE username = %s AND password = %s"
cursor.execute(query, (username, password))

PHP (PDO):
$query = "SELECT * FROM accounts WHERE username = :username AND password = :password";
$stmt = $pdo->prepare($query);
$stmt->bindParam(':username', $username);
$stmt->bindParam(':password', $password);
$stmt->execute();

Step 4: Handle Results Securely

  • Ensure that sensitive data is not exposed unnecessarily through query results.
  • Apply secure coding practices when processing query results (e.g., avoid writing sensitive data to logs).

Step 5: Test Prepared Statements Implementation

  • Test prepared statements by intentionally attempting to inject malicious SQL code.
  • Verify that prepared statements prevent the execution of injected SQL commands.

Further Considerations:

  • ORM Support: If using an ORM (e.g., Hibernate, SQLAlchemy), ensure that parameterized queries are supported and properly configured.
  • Stored Procedures: Use parameterized calls to stored procedures if available.
  • Logging and Monitoring: Monitor query logs for patterns indicating potential SQL injection attempts.

By following these steps, you can implement secure prepared statements and parameterized queries to protect the "Account" software component against SQL injection vulnerabilities.

reference.name: OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and captcha
countermeasure.desc:
Rate limiting and CAPTCHA help protect the "Account" software component against brute-force attacks, credential stuffing, and other abuse. Heres how to implement these mechanisms:

Step 1: Implement Rate Limiting

Choose a Rate Limiting Approach:

  • Fixed Window: Limit requests within fixed time windows (e.g., 5 requests per minute).
  • Sliding Window: Smooth out traffic patterns by counting requests over sliding intervals.
  • Token Bucket/Leaky Bucket: Allow bursts of requests up to a certain limit.

Configure Rate Limits:

  • Define rate limits per IP address or user account.
  • Example rules:
    • 5 login attempts per IP address per minute.
    • 3 password reset requests per user per hour.

Set Up Rate Limiting Middleware:

  • Use libraries or middleware that provide rate limiting.
    • Node.js: express-rate-limit
    • Python: Flask-Limiter, Django-Ratelimit
    • Java: Implement with ServletFilter or frameworks (e.g., Spring Security).

Step 2: Implement CAPTCHA

Select a CAPTCHA Service:

  • Choose a CAPTCHA implementation that best fits your application.
    • Traditional CAPTCHAs: Image-based tests like reCAPTCHA or hCaptcha.
    • Invisible CAPTCHAs: Automatically classify behavior patterns (e.g., reCAPTCHA v3).
    • Custom Solutions: Numerical questions or pattern matching.

Configure CAPTCHA Verification:

  • Require CAPTCHA verification only for critical actions or after repeated failed attempts.
  • For web forms:
    • Embed CAPTCHA widgets in forms requiring verification (e.g., login, registration).
    • Validate the CAPTCHA response server-side using the providers API.
  • For APIs:
    • Require a CAPTCHA token in the request payload and verify server-side.

Step 3: Monitor and Adjust Mechanisms

  • Monitor Traffic and Alerts:
    • Monitor rate limit logs for unusual patterns indicating potential attacks.
    • Log CAPTCHA validation failures for security analysis.
  • Adjust Thresholds:
    • Modify rate limiting and CAPTCHA thresholds based on normal traffic patterns and usability considerations.
  • Whitelist Trusted Sources:
    • Whitelist trusted IP addresses or users where appropriate, without compromising security.

Step 4: Educate Users and Provide Support

  • Usability:
    • Ensure CAPTCHA mechanisms do not overly inconvenience legitimate users.
  • Support Channels:
    • Provide support channels for users unable to pass CAPTCHA or facing accidental rate limits.

By implementing these steps, you can effectively protect the "Account" software component against common abuse patterns while maintaining a good user experience.

reference.name: CIS Controls for Effective Cyber Defense
OWASP Guide to Denial of Service Attacks

countermeasure.name: Implement robust access control mechanisms
countermeasure.desc:
Access control mechanisms ensure that users only have access to data and features they are authorized to interact with. Here's how to implement robust access control for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Identify User Roles and Permissions

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):
    • Identify distinct user roles (e.g., Admin, Moderator, Regular User).
    • List actions or resources each role can access.
  • Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC):
    • Define access rules based on user attributes (e.g., location, department) and contextual data (e.g., time of day).
  • Fine-Grained Permissions:
    • Specify granular permissions, particularly for sensitive actions (e.g., deleting accounts).

Step 2: Implement Authentication

  • Ensure authentication is robust before applying access controls:
    • Use strong password policies, multi-factor authentication (MFA), and secure session management.
    • Integrate Single Sign-On (SSO) if applicable.

Step 3: Implement Access Control Logic

  • Secure Back-End Endpoints:
    • Check user roles and permissions before granting access to endpoints.
    • Ensure that sensitive API routes and resources are protected.
    • Example: Apply a middleware or filter that verifies user roles and permissions.
  • Front-End Checks:
    • Implement client-side checks to limit access to UI features (e.g., hiding admin links from regular users).
    • However, enforce actual access controls on the server side.

Step 4: Apply the Principle of Least Privilege

  • Default Deny:
    • Deny access by default, requiring explicit permission to grant access to resources.
  • Granular Permissions:
    • Avoid overly broad permissions; instead, grant only the minimum necessary access.

Step 5: Audit and Monitor Access Control Rules

  • Audit Logs:
    • Log successful and failed access attempts for sensitive actions.
    • Keep audit logs secure and review them periodically.
  • Policy Review:
    • Regularly review access control rules for compliance and correctness.
    • Update rules as new roles or features are introduced.

Step 6: Test Access Control Mechanisms

  • Unit and Integration Testing:
    • Write automated tests to verify that roles and permissions work as intended.
  • Penetration Testing:
    • Test for potential bypasses or privilege escalation vulnerabilities.

Step 7: Provide User Education and Documentation

  • Educate users on why certain permissions are restricted and how they can request additional access if needed.
  • Document all roles and permissions clearly.

By following these steps, you can implement effective access control mechanisms that protect your "Account" software component against unauthorized access.

countermeasure.name: Proactive risk assessments for data protection
countermeasure.desc:
Proactive risk assessments help identify and mitigate potential risks to data before they lead to security incidents. Heres how to conduct proactive risk assessments for data protection in the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Inventory and Classify Data

  • Data Inventory:
    • Identify all types of data handled by the application (e.g., personal information, payment data, internal business data).
  • Data Classification:
    • Classify data into different sensitivity levels (e.g., public, internal, confidential, restricted).

Step 2: Identify Potential Risks

  • Threat Modeling:
    • Conduct threat modeling exercises to identify threats specific to your application.
    • Consider various attack vectors, including web attacks (e.g., XSS, SQL injection), social engineering, and insider threats.
  • Access Controls:
    • Review current access control measures for potential weaknesses or overly broad permissions.

Step 3: Analyze Existing Security Controls

  • Technical Controls:
    • Review current encryption standards, authentication mechanisms, and access controls.
    • Verify compliance with best practices and industry standards (e.g., NIST, ISO 27001).
  • Organizational Controls:
    • Ensure policies and training align with data protection goals.
    • Review incident response plans and data retention policies.

Step 4: Assess Impact and Likelihood of Risks

  • Impact Analysis:
    • Determine the potential impact of data breaches, unauthorized access, or data loss.
    • Consider regulatory fines, loss of customer trust, and business continuity issues.
  • Likelihood Estimation:
    • Estimate the probability of each risk materializing based on historical data, known vulnerabilities, and threat landscape.

Step 5: Develop Mitigation Strategies

  • Technical Mitigations:
    • Implement encryption (at rest and in transit), secure backups, access controls, and data masking.
  • Organizational Mitigations:
    • Conduct security awareness training, establish incident response procedures, and update policies.
  • Risk Acceptance or Transfer:
    • In some cases, accept risks with compensating controls or transfer them through cyber insurance.

Step 6: Document Findings and Plan

  • Risk Assessment Report:
    • Document identified risks, their potential impacts, and the proposed mitigation strategies.
    • Include a risk matrix or ranking for prioritization.
  • Action Plan:
    • Develop an action plan to implement mitigations, including timelines and responsible parties.

Step 7: Monitor and Review Risks Periodically

  • Continuous Monitoring:
    • Implement continuous monitoring of key risks to detect changes in the threat landscape.
  • Regular Reviews:
    • Conduct regular risk assessment reviews, especially after major changes or incidents.

By proactively assessing risks, you can better protect the "Account" software component's data and reduce the likelihood and impact of potential security incidents.

countermeasure.name: Regular configuration and vulnerability assessment
countermeasure.desc:
Regular configuration and vulnerability assessments are essential to maintain the security posture of the "Account" software component. Here's how to conduct them effectively:

Step 1: Create an Assessment Schedule

  • Frequency:
    • Perform assessments quarterly, or more frequently for critical systems.
    • Schedule assessments after major changes or updates.

Step 2: Inventory Assets and Configurations

  • Asset Inventory:
    • List all servers, databases, applications, and network components in your environment.
  • Configuration Baselines:
    • Establish secure baseline configurations for each system based on industry best practices (e.g., CIS Benchmarks).

Step 3: Configuration Assessment

  • Review System Configurations:
    • Compare the current configuration of each asset against the secure baseline.
    • Identify deviations that could lead to security vulnerabilities (e.g., unused open ports, weak passwords, disabled encryption).
  • Automate Assessments:
    • Use configuration management tools or scripts to automate the assessment process.

Step 4: Vulnerability Scanning

  • Run Automated Scans:
    • Use vulnerability scanners (e.g., Nessus, OpenVAS) to identify known vulnerabilities in your systems.
    • Include both infrastructure (servers, firewalls) and application-level (web apps, databases) scans.
  • Analyze Results:
    • Review scan results to identify critical vulnerabilities requiring immediate attention.

Step 5: Manual Penetration Testing

  • Test for Misconfigurations:
    • Conduct manual testing to identify security issues that automated scanners might miss.
    • Test for common misconfigurations, such as directory traversal or weak authentication.
  • Simulate Real-World Attacks:
    • Simulate real-world attack scenarios, such as privilege escalation or data exfiltration.

Step 6: Document and Prioritize Findings

  • Risk Assessment:
    • Assign severity levels to each finding based on potential impact and exploitability.
    • Prioritize remediation efforts based on business-critical systems and data.
  • Reports:
    • Provide comprehensive reports to stakeholders, detailing findings, impacts, and remediation recommendations.

Step 7: Implement Remediation Plans

  • Fix Issues Promptly:
    • Apply patches or updates, reconfigure systems, and enforce secure coding practices.
  • Verify Changes:
    • Reassess affected systems to ensure the vulnerabilities have been successfully addressed.

Step 8: Continuous Improvement

  • Feedback Loop:
    • Adjust configuration baselines and assessment procedures based on new vulnerabilities and security incidents.
  • Security Awareness:
    • Train your team to recognize common vulnerabilities and maintain secure configurations.

By following these steps, you can establish a proactive, continuous approach to securing the "Account" software component through regular configuration and vulnerability assessments.

countermeasure.name: Secure session management practices
countermeasure.desc:
Secure session management is crucial to protect user sessions from hijacking, fixation, and unauthorized access. Here's how to implement secure session management practices for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Establish Secure Session Tokens

  • Unique Identifiers:
    • Generate session tokens with cryptographically secure randomness, ensuring they're unique and unpredictable.
  • Token Length:
    • Use tokens with sufficient length (at least 128-bit) to prevent guessing or brute-force attacks.
  • Token Storage:
    • Store tokens securely on the server and client side (using secure cookies or HTTP headers).

Step 2: Implement Secure Cookie Settings

  • Secure Attribute:
    • Set the Secure attribute to ensure session cookies are only transmitted over HTTPS.
  • HttpOnly Attribute:
    • Set the HttpOnly attribute to prevent access to cookies via JavaScript.
  • SameSite Attribute:
    • Use the SameSite attribute to prevent cookies from being sent with cross-site requests (prefer SameSite=Strict or Lax).

Step 3: Ensure Session Expiration and Renewal

  • Idle Timeout:
    • Implement an idle timeout (e.g., 15-30 minutes of inactivity) to invalidate inactive sessions.
  • Absolute Timeout:
    • Set an absolute session expiration (e.g., 24 hours) to enforce periodic re-authentication.
  • Token Renewal:
    • Refresh tokens periodically to limit their lifetime, especially after sensitive actions.

Step 4: Mitigate Session Fixation

  • Regenerate Tokens:
    • Generate a new session token on login and other critical transitions (e.g., privilege escalation).
    • Invalidate old tokens to prevent reuse.
  • Token Validation:
    • Verify that tokens match the session state (e.g., user roles) and reject mismatches.

Step 5: Protect Against Session Hijacking

  • IP Address Matching:
    • Optionally associate sessions with client IP addresses or user agents, triggering a re-authentication if they change.
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
    • Require MFA for critical actions or logins from new devices.
  • Intrusion Detection:
    • Monitor for unusual session activity, such as simultaneous logins from different regions.

Step 6: Implement Logging and Auditing

  • Session Logs:
    • Log session creation, termination, and any security-related actions.
  • Alerting:
    • Set up alerts for suspicious session activities, like repeated token changes or session reuse.

Step 7: Educate Users

  • Security Awareness:
    • Inform users about security best practices (e.g., avoiding shared computers, logging out after use).
  • Self-Service Features:
    • Provide tools for users to view active sessions and terminate any they do not recognize.

By following these practices, you can create a robust session management system that securely handles user sessions in the "Account" software component.

countermeasure.name: Use of secure defaults and hardening guides
countermeasure.desc:
Using secure defaults and hardening guides ensures that the "Account" software component starts from a secure baseline and minimizes its attack surface. Here's how to implement secure defaults and hardening practices effectively:

Step 1: Establish Secure Defaults

Configuration Defaults:

  • Set up application, database, and server configurations with conservative security settings by default.
  • Disable unused services and features that can expand the attack surface (e.g., default database accounts).

Password Policies:

  • Enforce strong default password policies (e.g., minimum length, complexity requirements).
  • Disable or limit default accounts and credentials.

Access Controls:

  • Apply least privilege as the default permission setting for new accounts or roles.
  • Deny access to sensitive features or data unless explicitly permitted.

Secure Transport:

  • Enforce HTTPS as the default transport protocol, redirecting HTTP traffic automatically.
  • Set secure defaults for cookies (e.g., Secure, HttpOnly, SameSite attributes).

Step 2: Apply Hardening Guides

Operating System Hardening:

  • Follow recognized OS hardening guidelines like CIS Benchmarks or government recommendations.
  • Remove unnecessary software packages, disable unused network services, and apply restrictive firewall rules.

Application Hardening:

  • Enable security features like Content Security Policy (CSP) and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) restrictions.
  • Ensure all third-party libraries or plugins are up-to-date and supported.

Database Hardening:

  • Restrict database access to required users and applications only.
  • Disable unused features and configure secure defaults (e.g., encryption in transit, user auditing).

Network Hardening:

  • Limit network exposure by placing the application behind a web application firewall (WAF) and reverse proxy.
  • Implement logging and intrusion detection for critical traffic.

Step 3: Test Hardening and Secure Defaults

Automated Testing:

  • Integrate automated security testing tools that verify default configurations meet established baselines.
  • Perform regular vulnerability scans to identify misconfigurations and unpatched components.

Manual Testing:

  • Conduct manual security reviews to ensure secure defaults are consistently applied.
  • Validate that hardening configurations are compatible with functional requirements.

Step 4: Update Hardening Guides Regularly

  • Threat Landscape Awareness:
    • Stay informed about emerging threats and vulnerabilities affecting your technology stack.
  • Guideline Updates:
    • Review and update hardening guidelines periodically to reflect changing best practices.
    • Share updated guidelines across the team to ensure consistent implementation.

By implementing these secure defaults and hardening practices, you establish a secure foundation for the "Account" software component and minimize the risk of successful attacks.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion through account enumeration attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Resource exhaustion through account enumeration attacks is a form of brute force attack where an attacker attempts to identify valid user accounts within a system by exploiting specific feedback mechanisms, typically through login pages or API responses. Once accounts are identified, the attacker continues to bombard them with numerous authentication attempts. This attack seeks to overwhelm the system's resources (e.g., CPU, memory, bandwidth), often causing degraded performance, denial of service (DoS), or data compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Threat actors often include hackers, organized cybercriminals, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Login forms or APIs that provide differing responses for valid and invalid usernames.
    • Forgot-password or account recovery pages that reveal user account existence.
    • Publicly accessible directories or registration forms that can be exploited for brute force or enumeration attacks.

Impacts

  • Resource Exhaustion: The system's resources become strained due to an excessive number of authentication attempts.
  • Denial of Service (DoS): Other legitimate services can become unavailable due to excessive resource usage.
  • Account Lockout: Valid users may be locked out of their accounts if the system implements automatic lockouts after a certain number of failed login attempts.
  • Data Exposure: Attackers might gather valid usernames or email addresses for future targeted attacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Username Discovery via Login Response

  • An attacker submits multiple usernames in a login form.
  • The system differentiates between valid and invalid usernames via error messages.
  • The attacker identifies active accounts and attempts resource-exhaustion attacks on them.

Scenario 2: Account Lockout by Brute Force

  • An attacker discovers valid usernames via enumeration techniques.
  • They then attempt numerous login attempts, causing legitimate users to be locked out due to the systems security policies.
  • This flood of login attempts strains server resources, slowing down other services.

Scenario 3: Automated Enumeration via API

  • The attacker programs a bot to send rapid API requests.
  • The API's error messages reveal which usernames are valid.
  • The attacker uses these accounts to conduct brute-force password attacks, causing a sharp spike in resource consumption.

Mitigation strategies include rate limiting, CAPTCHA implementations, standardized error messages, and account behavior analysis.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers gain elevated privilege
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The threat of attackers gaining elevated privilege is a significant concern for software components that handle sensitive data, like an account management system. This type of attack occurs when unauthorized individuals manipulate vulnerabilities within the system to gain privileges above their assigned level. Such unauthorized privilege escalation enables attackers to perform operations they normally couldn't, potentially leading to extensive system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  1. Threat Agents: The primary threat agents include external hackers, insider threats (disgruntled employees, for instance), and advanced persistent threat (APT) groups targeting critical data. Insider threats often possess initial access credentials, increasing the attacks effectiveness.
  2. Attack Vectors:
    • Vulnerable Software: Bugs or logic flaws in the software allowing users to circumvent privilege verification.
    • Weak Authentication: Poor authentication mechanisms, like insecure password policies or multi-factor authentication misconfigurations.
    • Misconfigured Access Controls: Incorrectly set permissions or policies enabling access beyond the users role.
    • Social Engineering: Phishing or other manipulation techniques to gain initial low-privilege access and then escalate.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Access to sensitive personal or financial data stored in the account system.
  2. System Compromise: Complete control over user accounts or administrative functions, leading to further exploitation.
  3. Financial Loss: Theft of funds, fraudulent transactions, or damage to business operations.
  4. Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from clients or partners due to inadequate security.

Example Attack Scenarios

Vulnerable API: An attacker identifies an insecure API endpoint within the account management system. By crafting specific requests that exploit input validation flaws, they manage to execute administrative commands, gaining full system access.

Misconfigured Access Control: An insider user in a non-administrative role discovers that certain backend administrative pages lack proper access controls. By directly accessing these pages, the user bypasses role-based restrictions and modifies account settings for other users.

Brute Force on Admin Account: An attacker gains access to a low-level account through a phishing attack. From there, they analyze username structures and identify an admin user account. They then use brute force techniques to compromise the admin account and escalate their privileges.

Malicious Insider: A disgruntled employee with a customer support role intentionally misuses their elevated permissions to deactivate security features for their account, allowing them unrestricted access to sensitive information.

The potential impacts of these scenarios highlight the need for strong, multi-layered security controls, routine monitoring, and thorough vulnerability management to mitigate risks.

threat.name: Attackers use improper security configuration for malicious activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improper security configurations refer to incorrect or suboptimal settings that inadvertently provide attackers with exploitable vulnerabilities. When system components like databases, servers, web applications, or cloud services are misconfigured, attackers can manipulate these settings to bypass authentication, execute malicious code, access sensitive data, or launch further attacks. This improper configuration is often due to default settings, lack of configuration review, or insufficient security policies.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • Cybercriminals who scan for known vulnerabilities in popular software configurations.
  • Insider threats that leverage their internal knowledge for personal gain or revenge.
  • Script kiddies who use automated tools to exploit misconfigured systems.

Attack Vectors

  • Open ports left unnecessarily exposed to the internet.
  • Databases and directories accessible without proper authentication.
  • Web server files and admin panels left publicly visible.
  • Inadequate permissions on sensitive resources like APIs, storage buckets, or management consoles.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can gain access to internal networks, systems, and sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Manipulating configurations may lead to Denial of Service (DoS), which can disable critical services.
  • Data Breach: Exposure of private data, like customer information or intellectual property, can occur.
  • Privilege Escalation: Attackers may leverage minor misconfigurations to gain administrator-level control over systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Open Management Port

  • A database management port remains publicly accessible with a default or weak password.
  • An attacker locates the port through internet-wide scans and logs into the database.
  • The attacker exfiltrates sensitive customer data.

Scenario 2: Misconfigured Web Server

  • A web server is left with directory browsing enabled, exposing the directory structure and files.
  • An attacker explores these directories, finding configuration files containing credentials.
  • Using these credentials, the attacker accesses internal systems and customer data.

Scenario 3: Publicly Accessible Cloud Storage

  • A cloud storage bucket is misconfigured, leaving it publicly readable and writable.
  • An attacker discovers the bucket and uploads malicious files that redirect legitimate users to phishing sites.
  • Users who download sensitive files from the bucket unknowingly download malware.

Mitigations include implementing security best practices, routine vulnerability scanning, consistent patching, proper access controls, configuration management, and regular security audits.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers obtain unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to a situation where attackers gain entry into a software component without proper authorization. For an account management system, this means circumventing authentication or authorization controls to access accounts, user data, or administrative functions. This unauthorized entry often serves as a stepping stone for further attacks such as data exfiltration, privilege escalation, or denial-of-service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • External hackers seeking to exploit security flaws to gain access to sensitive systems.
  • Malicious insiders misusing their current privileges to infiltrate restricted parts of the system.
  • Competitors or state-sponsored groups targeting proprietary or personal data.

Attack Vectors:

  • Brute Force Attacks: Repeated attempts to guess passwords until successful, particularly where weak or reused credentials are used.
  • Phishing/Social Engineering: Manipulating users into revealing their credentials or installing malware.
  • Vulnerable APIs or Web Applications: Exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities in application code to bypass authentication mechanisms.
  • Credential Stuffing: Using lists of breached passwords to gain access to accounts using reused passwords.
  • Physical Security Gaps: Directly accessing systems via physical means (e.g., stolen devices or insecure network access).

Impacts

  1. Data Theft: Compromising personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and proprietary business information.
  2. Account Takeover: Hijacking accounts to conduct fraud, impersonation, or malicious activities under a legitimate users identity.
  3. Service Disruption: Altering or disabling account settings that can disrupt normal service operations.
  4. Legal and Regulatory Penalties: Non-compliance with data security regulations may lead to fines or sanctions.

Example Attack Scenarios

Phishing Attack: An attacker sends convincing phishing emails to employees that mimic an official company email, tricking users into providing their login credentials via a fake login page. The attacker then uses these credentials to gain unauthorized access to the system.

Unpatched Software: An account management application has a known vulnerability that the development team hasn't yet patched. The attacker scans for this software version, exploits the vulnerability to bypass authentication, and gains control over user accounts.

Insider Attack: An employee with legitimate access to user accounts steals login credentials or directly accesses user data, providing this information to an external malicious entity.

Credential Stuffing: The attacker uses a list of known breached passwords from a different service to attempt logins to the account system. Many users reuse passwords, allowing the attacker to successfully log into their accounts.

Mitigation Strategies

To reduce the risks of unauthorized access, consider implementing multi-factor authentication, rate-limiting login attempts, robust security training for employees, and regular audits of software security.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of poor protected data and insecure communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers exploiting poorly protected data and insecure communications refers to cybercriminals targeting unencrypted, weakly encrypted, or improperly managed sensitive information. This includes data stored locally, transmitted over networks, or accessed through insecure channels. Without strong encryption or secure protocols, attackers can intercept, tamper with, or steal data, leading to financial loss, privacy violations, and further attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents

  • Cybercriminals seeking to steal data for financial gain or extortion.
  • Nation-state actors involved in espionage and surveillance activities.
  • Insider threats leveraging insecure data channels for personal or competitive advantage.

Attack Vectors

  • Public Wi-Fi networks that transmit unencrypted data.
  • Web applications using outdated security protocols (e.g., SSL instead of TLS).
  • Storage devices with poor encryption or easily guessable passwords.
  • APIs lacking encryption or access control.
  • Poorly secured file transfers via email, FTP, or other channels.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties, potentially leading to identity theft or intellectual property loss.
  • Financial Loss: Victims may suffer direct financial losses or face costly compliance fines due to the breach.
  • Reputational Damage: Organizations may lose customer trust due to leaked customer data or compromised communication channels.
  • Espionage: Sensitive corporate or governmental data may be stolen for strategic, financial, or political advantage.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Eavesdropping on Public Wi-Fi

  • An attacker sets up a fake Wi-Fi hotspot in a public location (e.g., caf, airport).
  • Users unknowingly connect to the hotspot, transmitting their personal and business data in plaintext.
  • The attacker intercepts the unencrypted traffic, gaining access to login credentials and sensitive information.

Scenario 2: Insecure Communication Protocol

  • A web application uses outdated or insecure communication protocols like SSL or HTTP instead of HTTPS.
  • The attacker uses a "man-in-the-middle" attack to intercept sensitive data transmitted between the client and server.
  • The attacker gains access to confidential information like passwords and private messages.

Scenario 3: Unprotected Storage Devices

  • An organization stores sensitive data on portable USB drives without encryption.
  • An insider or thief steals the USB drives and accesses the data directly due to a lack of encryption or access control.

Mitigations include encrypting all data at rest and in transit, using secure communication protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+), regularly updating software, implementing multi-factor authentication, and monitoring data access.

threat.name: Information disclosure through improper handling of user data and error messages
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Information disclosure through improper handling of user data and error messages refers to unintentionally exposing sensitive information due to misconfigured system behavior or poor data sanitization practices. This exposure can occur through debugging messages, exception details, or inadvertent data leakage. Attackers can use this information to gain insights into internal workings, identify weaknesses, and subsequently launch more targeted attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • External Hackers: Hackers seeking to discover internal system details to identify exploitable vulnerabilities.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent insiders with knowledge of system behavior, leveraging access to error messages or misconfigured components.
  • Competitors/State Actors: Groups seeking competitive or strategic advantage by gathering sensitive or proprietary information.

Attack Vectors:

  • Error Messages: Inadequate handling of error messages that reveal sensitive information, like usernames, system paths, or application structure.
  • Logging Practices: Logging user inputs or sensitive details without appropriate sanitization or encryption.
  • Debugging Information: Exposing detailed debugging information in production environments, which can include database queries or stack traces.
  • Misconfigured Access: Allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive pages due to incorrect access control.

Impacts

  1. Sensitive Information Exposure: Revealing customer data, proprietary business information, or other confidential details.
  2. Security Vulnerability Identification: Allowing attackers to identify internal weaknesses like database structure, server configurations, or software versions.
  3. Reputational Damage: Eroding customer trust by inadvertently disclosing their data.
  4. Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with privacy regulations due to exposure of protected information.

Example Attack Scenarios

Verbose Error Messages: An attacker intentionally triggers error conditions, and verbose error messages disclose sensitive data such as file paths or database query structures that hint at exploitable vulnerabilities.

Logging Insufficient Sanitization: Application logs record user input data without adequate sanitization, exposing personal information or credentials. An attacker who gains access to these logs can read sensitive details.

Debugging Information: A developer leaves detailed debugging messages enabled in production. An attacker sees these messages, which contain database error details, giving clues to the schema and potential injection points.

Access Control Misconfiguration: Error messages generated on unauthorized access attempts reveal information about valid usernames or resources that should be kept hidden.

Mitigation Strategies

  1. Input Validation and Sanitization: Properly validate and sanitize user input before logging or processing.
  2. Controlled Error Messaging: Configure user-facing error messages to be generic while logging detailed technical information securely for administrators.
  3. Production Debugging Policies: Disable debugging information in production environments, ensuring only high-level error messages are visible to end-users.
  4. Access Control Audits: Regularly audit access control configurations to prevent unintended data disclosure.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Unnoticed misbehaviour due to insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unnoticed misbehavior due to insufficient logging and monitoring happens when security incidents or malicious activity go undetected because of a lack of comprehensive logging or inadequate monitoring of system events. Without proper logs and real-time alerts, attacks can progress unimpeded, allowing adversaries to cause significant damage or remain persistent in the network for extended periods.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents

  • External attackers who exploit vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access or compromise systems.
  • Malicious insiders who abuse legitimate privileges for espionage, sabotage, or data theft.
  • Automated bots scanning networks for open ports or insecure services.

Attack Vectors

  • Gaining unauthorized access through weak credentials or unpatched vulnerabilities.
  • Privilege escalation and lateral movement across systems undetected due to missing or weak logging.
  • Disabling or evading logging mechanisms as part of an attack strategy.

Impacts

  • Delayed Incident Response: Without sufficient logging and monitoring, security incidents are recognized too late, increasing response time and potential damage.
  • Extended System Compromise: Attackers can persist in the system, collecting data or spreading malware due to the absence of immediate detection.
  • Data Breach: Compromised data may lead to compliance violations, financial losses, and reputational damage.
  • Business Disruption: Critical services might be disrupted if malicious actions remain undetected.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Web Server Exploitation

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in a web application that lacks proper logging.
  • They install a web shell, granting them persistent backdoor access.
  • Without detection mechanisms, the attacker extracts sensitive data over time without being noticed.

Scenario 2: Insider Data Theft

  • An insider downloads a large number of files from internal databases.
  • Because of insufficient logging or lack of alerting thresholds, this activity is not flagged as suspicious.
  • The insider sells or leaks proprietary data externally, unnoticed.

Scenario 3: Ransomware Infection

  • A phishing email delivers a ransomware payload that encrypts files on the infected machine.
  • The compromised device's activity is not logged, so the encryption remains unnoticed.
  • The ransomware spreads across the network, infecting other machines, and eventually leading to a widespread system lockdown.

Mitigation measures include implementing centralized logging systems, ensuring logs are comprehensive and immutable, configuring alerts for unusual activities, and regularly reviewing logs for suspicious patterns. Furthermore, organizations should deploy security information and event management (SIEM) solutions for real-time monitoring and automated alerts.

reference.name: OWASP Log Forging Prevention Cheat Sheet

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1199 - Trusted Relationship||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1557 - Adversary-in-the-Middle||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562 - Impair Defenses||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Injection attacks occur when attackers insert malicious code into an input field or request to manipulate or exploit a vulnerable software system. This type of attack can lead to unauthorized access, data leakage, data manipulation, and even system compromise. Common forms include SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and command injection. These attacks leverage unvalidated or improperly sanitized input to execute unintended commands or queries.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • External Hackers: Cybercriminals seeking unauthorized access or data manipulation via vulnerable input fields.
  • Malicious Insiders: Employees or other internal users who exploit their knowledge of system weaknesses.
  • Automated Bots: Tools specifically designed to scan and exploit injection vulnerabilities on a large scale.

Attack Vectors:

  • SQL Injection: Manipulating SQL queries via web application input fields to gain access to databases or modify data.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): Injecting client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users to steal data or compromise their sessions.
  • Command Injection: Injecting operating system commands through an application's input to execute unauthorized actions.
  • LDAP Injection: Exploiting input validation flaws to alter LDAP queries and access sensitive information.

Impacts

  1. Data Theft: Access to sensitive or proprietary data stored in the system.
  2. Data Manipulation: Unauthorized alteration or deletion of records in the database.
  3. Account Compromise: Unauthorized access to user accounts, potentially enabling privilege escalation or session hijacking.
  4. System Control: Complete system compromise, allowing attackers to execute arbitrary commands or deploy malware.

Example Attack Scenarios

SQL Injection: An attacker submits a crafted input, such as '; DROP TABLE users; --, into a vulnerable web form that executes SQL queries without proper sanitization. This input tricks the database into deleting the entire user table.

Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): An attacker injects a <script> tag into a comment section of a web page, exploiting the application's lack of input filtering. When other users view the page, their browsers execute the script, sending their session cookies to the attacker.

Command Injection: An application allows users to execute system commands via a web interface. An attacker injects commands like ; rm -rf / into a field, causing the server to delete important files.

LDAP Injection: An attacker submits malicious input to manipulate an LDAP search query, enabling them to gain unauthorized access to parts of the LDAP directory.

Mitigation Strategies

  1. Input Validation and Sanitization: Ensure that all user inputs are validated and sanitized before being processed or stored.
  2. Parameterized Queries/Prepared Statements: Use parameterized queries for database operations to prevent SQL injection.
  3. Content Security Policy (CSP): Implement CSP to mitigate the impact of XSS attacks.
  4. Least Privilege Principle: Limit user access rights to the minimum required for their roles.
  5. Error Handling and Logging: Implement proper error handling to avoid exposing sensitive details, and log suspicious activities for further analysis.

reference.name: OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Define resource sharing boundaries in AWS RAM
countermeasure.desc: Establish clear boundaries within AWS RAM to limit which resources can be shared across accounts or organizational units. Use AWS RAM policies to explicitly define which resources are shareable and restrict access to only authorized accounts or organizations. Regularly review shared resource configurations to ensure that sensitive resources, such as databases or VPCs, are excluded from cross-account sharing unless explicitly required. Implement logging and monitoring to track shared resource usage and adjust boundaries as necessary to maintain security.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource types available for sharing in AWS RAM
countermeasure.desc: Limit the types of resources that can be shared through AWS RAM to exclude sensitive or critical assets, such as encryption keys or databases. When setting up resource sharing, explicitly define resource types that are eligible for sharing and prevent sensitive items from being exposed to cross-account sharing. Regularly audit shared resources to ensure critical assets remain isolated and secure. Use tagging and resource classification to automate and streamline resource-sharing restrictions.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Untrusted cross-account access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Allowing untrusted or unauthorized AWS accounts to access shared resources through AWS RAM can lead to resource misuse, data breaches, or unintended resource modifications.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, misconfigured IAM roles, or unverified accounts may exploit cross-account sharing to access resources inappropriately.

Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive resources, data leakage, and potential service disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios
A misconfigured cross-account invitation allows an untrusted AWS account to gain access to critical resources, which results in resource misuse and data extraction.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sharing sensitive resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sharing sensitive or critical resources through AWS RAM without proper restrictions can expose data or systems to unauthorized users, increasing the risk of data breaches or misuse.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or misconfigured sharing policies that unintentionally expose sensitive resources such as databases, VPCs, or encryption keys.

Impacts
Data leakage, unauthorized access to critical infrastructure, potential regulatory compliance violations, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios
A sensitive S3 bucket containing financial data is shared with external AWS accounts, leading to unauthorized access and data breaches.

threat.name: Inadequate resource sharing boundaries
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper configuration of resource sharing boundaries in AWS RAM can result in shared resources being accessible to unintended or unauthorized accounts or entities, leading to security and privacy risks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigured sharing settings, overly permissive IAM policies, or lack of proper review on shared resource boundaries.

Impacts
Unauthorized access, data leakage, unintended modification or deletion of resources.

Example Attack Scenarios
A resource is shared across an entire organization when it should be restricted to specific accounts, leading to unauthorized access and unintentional data exposure.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Define IAM policies for Distributed Map state
countermeasure.desc: When you create workflows with the Step Functions console, Step Functions can automatically generate IAM policies based on the resources in your workflow definition. These policies include the least privileges necessary to allow the state machine role to invoke the StartExecution API action for the Distributed Map state. These policies also include the least privileges necessary Step Functions to access AWS resources, such as Amazon S3 buckets and objects and Lambda functions. We highly recommend that you include only those permissions that are necessary in your IAM policies. For example, if your workflow includes a Map state in Distributed mode, scope your policies down to the specific Amazon S3 bucket and folder that contains your dataset.

reference.name: IAM policies for using Distributed Map state

countermeasure.name: Do not put sensitive data into AWS Step Functions free-form fields
countermeasure.desc: Do not put sensitive identifying information, such as your customers' email addresses, into tags or free-form text fields such as a Name field. This includes when you work with Step Functions or other AWS services using the console, API, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs. Any data that you enter into tags or free-form text fields used for names may be used for billing or diagnostic logs. If you provide a URL to an external server, we strongly recommend that you do not include credentials information in the URL to validate your request to that server.

reference.name: Data protection in AWS Step Functions

countermeasure.name: Use VPC Endpoints to ensure Step Functions communicate with other services securely
countermeasure.desc:
If you use Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) to host your AWS resources, you can establish a connection between your Amazon VPC and AWS Step Functions workflows. You can use this connection with your Step Functions workflows without crossing the public internet. Amazon VPC endpoints are supported by Standard Workflows, Express Workflows, and Synchronous Express Workflows.

Amazon VPC lets you launch AWS resources in a custom virtual network. You can use a VPC to control your network settings, such as the IP address range, subnets, route tables, and network gateways. For more information about VPCs, see the Amazon VPC User Guide.

To connect your Amazon VPC to Step Functions, you must first define an interface VPC endpoint, which lets you connect your VPC to other AWS services. The endpoint provides reliable, scalable connectivity, without requiring an internet gateway, network address translation (NAT) instance, or VPN connection. For more information, see Interface VPC Endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) in the Amazon VPC User Guide.

reference.name: Amazon VPC Endpoints for Step Functions

countermeasure.name: Use WS User Notifications with Step Functions
countermeasure.desc: You can use AWS User Notifications to receive alerts and notifications for security-related events in Step Functions. You receive a notification when an event matches a rule that you specify. You can receive notifications for events through multiple channels, including email, AWS Chatbot chat notifications, or AWS Console Mobile Application push notifications. You can also see notifications in the Console Notifications Center. User Notifications supports aggregation, which can reduce the number of notifications you receive during specific events.

reference.name: Using AWS User Notifications with AWS Step Functions

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Uncontrolled parallel workloads
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat refers to the scenario where an excessively high amount of parallel workloads are implemented without proper control or management. Such a situation can stress the resources and infrastructure, yielding increased costs and weak performance.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfiguration is a common cause of this threat. It could be due to inadvertent errors by administrators failing to manage the workload effectively. Alternatively, malicious actors might manipulate the workload configuration to initiate a Denial of Service (DoS) attack.
Impacts
Overloading the system with uncontrolled parallel workloads can cause excessive resource utilization, leading to severe system slowdown or potential downtime. In a pay-as-you-go environment like AWS, it may result in significant unexpected costs. Besides, it may impact the service availability negatively, disrupting business operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An accidental misconfiguration by an admin can trigger a mass parallel execution of workloads that exceed the set limits, straining the resources and causing potential unavailability of services. Another scenario could be a malicious internal user or hacker who intentionally modifies the configuration to initiate uncontrolled parallel execution, resulting in a DoS attack.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Unsecured communication with AWS Services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unsecured Communication with AWS Services refers to a situation wherein the communication between the AWS Step Functions and other AWS services is not properly encrypted or secured. This could potentially expose sensitive data in transit, or allow unauthorized modification of data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This vulnerability can be exploited by cyber attackers who intercept the communication between AWS services. They can do so through man-in-the-middle attacks, traffic sniffing, or even through accessing insecure network configurations.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breach, unexpected charges from compromised AWS resources, loss of data integrity, and loss of customer trust due to security incidents.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might intercept unencrypted traffic between AWS Step Functions and another AWS service, enabling them to access, manipulate, or redirect the unsecured data. Alternatively, attackers might gain unauthorized access by exploiting the insecure network configuration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1043 - Commonly Used Port||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

threat.name: Lack of notifications for security events
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves the potential risk associated with not receiving crucial notifications for security-related events within AWS Step Functions service. Not receiving alerts for these events might leave the system vulnerable to malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could be internal or external attackers, or even automated scripts, which exploit the lack of proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms. This could lead to successful unauthorized activities like data breaches or system disruptions.
Impacts
The major impact includes potential system and data compromise, leading to Integrity, Confidentiality, and Availability (CIA) losses. It may also result in non-compliance with certain regulatory requirements that mandate the use of alerting mechanisms, subsequently leading to legal and financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker, having gained access to AWS Step Functions, carries out malicious activities including data exfiltration or service manipulation. However, due to the lack of proper notifications, these actions go unnoticed until significant damage is done.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General threat description
This refers to a situation where protective measures on data are bypassed, leading to exposure of sensitive information held within AWS Step Functions. This typically occurs when ill-intended individuals or packet sniffers exploit weak security systems to access data that they are not authorized to view. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents for this type of cyber threat could be internal or external adversaries who might engage in activities like spear phishing, password cracking, or exploiting vulnerabilities in security systems. Attack vectors could include malware, man-in-the-middle attacks, or exploits that compromise the AWS security environment. Impacts
The resultant impact includes potential loss of private and confidential business customer information, which might cause damage to business reputation, regulatory fines due to non-compliance with data protection laws, or even potential financial loss. 

Example Attack Scenarios
One example of such an attack can be when an attacker compromises an AWS identity with high-level permissions allowing access to AWS Step Functions. This can be achieved through spear phishing or brute force attacks, and once they have this access, they can view or exfiltrate sensitive data, undermining the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-233
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-233: Improper Handling of Parameters The product does not properly handle when the expected number of parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those parameters are undefined.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-476
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-476: NULL Pointer Dereference A NULL pointer dereference occurs when the application dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid, but is NULL, typically causing a crash or exit. NULL pointer dereference issues can occur through a number of flaws, including race conditions, and simple programming omissions.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Assign unique Autonomous System Numbers (ASN) for each Transit Gateway in multi-region deployments
countermeasure.desc: In multi-Region deployments, assign a unique Autonomous System Number (ASN) to each AWS Transit Gateway to prevent routing conflicts. This ensures that the routing tables between Regions remain independent, avoiding the risk of misrouted traffic or network instability. Use the AWS Management Console or CLI to configure distinct ASNs for each Transit Gateway during setup. Regularly audit the ASN assignments across Regions to maintain routing consistency and avoid conflicts that could impact network performance.

countermeasure.name: Enable route propagation for BGP Site-to-Site VPN and Direct Connect attachments
countermeasure.desc:
Security control description:
Ensure route propagation is enabled for all BGP Site-to-Site VPN and Direct Connect attachments in AWS Transit Gateway to maintain proper routing and network stability. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the Transit Gateway route tables and verify that route propagation is turned on for these connections. This ensures that dynamic routing changes are automatically updated and applied, preventing traffic loss or disruptions due to misconfigured routes. Regularly audit route configurations to ensure continued compliance.

countermeasure.name: Implement redundant Transit Gateway per region for disaster recovery
countermeasure.desc: Deploy a single AWS Transit Gateway per Region to ensure redundancy and support disaster recovery. This avoids a single point of failure and improves overall network availability. Use multiple Transit Gateways in different Regions to distribute traffic and provide failover capabilities in case of regional outages. Configure route tables and VPC attachments in each Region to ensure seamless communication. Regularly test the disaster recovery setup to verify that failover mechanisms are functioning as expected.

Having unnecessary route tables can lead to complex routing and suboptimal traffic flow. In the AWS Management Console, review the Transit Gateway route tables and consolidate them where possible. Ensure that only necessary route tables are in place to simplify network management and improve traffic efficiency. Regularly audit the routing setup for optimization opportunities.

countermeasure.name: Update both VPCs simultaneously during migrations to avoid MTU mismatches
countermeasure.desc: During VPC migrations, ensure both VPCs are updated simultaneously to prevent mismatches in Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) settings. Mismatched MTUs can cause packet drops and network disruptions. Use the AWS Management Console or automation tools to coordinate updates between VPCs, ensuring that both VPCs are configured with matching MTU settings. This helps maintain seamless traffic flow and reduces the risk of packet loss. Regularly monitor network performance to detect and resolve any MTU-related issues.
